talk.start.para: —I thank my colleagues and the Senate. There were also some concerns expressed last Monday morning about what might happen in the future. Again, to get that into perspective, I go back to the debate about the Iraqis. Mr Metcalfe, the Deputy Secretary of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, told the committee in his opening statement:

speech.para: . . . the United Nations estimated that there are approximately four million Iraqi nationals living outside Iraq and, of these, some 500,000 are estimated to be living in Iran. An analysis of some 180 of the recent Iraqi unauthorised boat arrivals indicates that over 60 per cent claim to have been resident in Iran, 39 per cent of these for over 10 years.

The Senate was told yesterday about Iraqi nationals in Iran being told to get out of that country by the early part of next year. If that is true, the world has a problem. Not just Australia but the world has a problem, because these people are moving to other parts of the world. This matter must be addressed by the international community. Australia must be in the forefront because we are experiencing it now, and we call for the international community to address those concerns. That may be at some cost to Australian taxpayers, but we should be proud to do that because we are a developed country that can afford to help those who are in greater need.

I think what I have just suggested is the proper course of action to address the problem, not allowing for just those individuals of Iraqi nationality who are currently enjoying sanctuary in Iran. Those who have the money, and only those who have the money, will be able to buy passage to Australia. That should not be allowed to continue, not just because of the problem it presents to Australia and the people of Australia but because of the unfairness of the situation. If people are deserving of protection because of the political views they hold, they should be provided with that protection, and it should not matter whether they have money or not.

I got upset yesterday and resisted the temptation to intervene in the debate. I think the message I was trying to convey yesterday was turned around somewhat by my colleague Senator Harradine, who said:

Senator McKiernan appeared to be setting up a division and a conflict between those asylum seekers and those who have been acknowledged by UNHCR as being refugees and who would then be given the necessary papers to come to Australia.

I am not seeking to set up any division between those people at all. I very firmly said yesterday that, if people come to our shores illegally, we have a right and an obligation to process their claims. What I am concerned about is the divisions that have been set up by others—divisions where if you have got money you can come to Australia and claim protection, but if you have not got money you languish in a queue for years and years at the overseas posts. You languish in a queue to get into the UNHCR stream and then, after you have been in the UNHCR stream, you get in a further queue in order to get the papers processed.

I tried to illustrate yesterday the successes we have had in getting some of those unfortunate people into Australia, and they were but small examples. I did incidentally, during the course of my contribution yesterday, acknowledge that many other parliamentarians did the same thing. I would add, however, that I very rarely go to the minister's office. We use proper process, because proper process is laid down. That is not to say that I never go to the minister's office, as those in the minister's office would know. I hope that that straightens out the record somewhat.

I want to make a quick comment about a matter that Senator Bartlett referred to yesterday afternoon in talking about people sitting on a boat for weeks on end and needing shampoo at the end of it. Indeed, if you did sit on a boat for weeks on end, you probably would need shampoo. But what is happening at the moment is not boat people sitting on rickety, shaky boats for weeks on end. It is a skip and a jump from Roti to Australia and no great journey at all from Indonesia to the Ashmore Reef. That is where they are coming in and that is where we are rescuing them from. It is not a revisiting of Australia's experience with the Chinese people and the Sino-Vietnamese coming out of China or the Vietnamese boat people earlier: they are coming very quickly and they are very well organised. They are coming because they have got the money to pay their passage to come.

I wish to refer very briefly—because I do not want to delay the Senate in the passage of this bill that we are all agreed upon—to Senator Harris's comments about the conviction of some people-smugglers earlier this week in Darwin and the sentences that were handed out to them. I am not going to comment on the sentences, because I have not read the judgment. It is important that, before public figures make any comment on the decisions of the judiciary. they at least read the judgment and, as the judge or magistrate has done, take all the circumstances into account and understand why the judge or magistrate arrived at the decision that they did.

Certainly, the penalties are there to provide for 20 years jail for convicted people-smugglers. The sentence that was handed out was two years, with a parole period of one year—which appears light, on the surface. It is my understanding that the people who were convicted were merely the people who guided the boat in—people who got just a few hundred dollars for undertaking the passage on behalf of others, not the people who benefited by the vast amounts of money that have been paid by the unfortunates for their smuggling. They are the people that we have got to target.

Unfortunately, it would seem that most of the organisers of these smuggling rings—at least, if we believe some of the media comment—are not present in Australia and therefore may be immune from Australia's laws. We have to seek international cooperation to target those people-smugglers, and not just target the poor old fishermen—many of whom are on a subsistence living and, when they are given a charter for a boat to come to Australia, grab it with both hands because of the economic difficulties that beset their lives back home. We have to take those things into consideration, and I would hope that perhaps these were the matters that the judge or magistrate in Darwin earlier in the week did take into consideration in arriving at the level of sentence. More, indeed, needs to be done. The bill is a further step in the protection of Australia by giving the system more streamlined conditions.

I conclude my remarks perhaps on a downside because of what I heard on the radio this morning, reported firstly in the news very early in the morning and later on in the ABC's AM program. It was a statement by President Wahid of Indonesia that the current problem of people smugglers was Australia's problem. That was a very unfortunate comment. I am receiving a message from the reported statement by the president—I believe his voice was actually used in the AM program later—that he is going to wash his hands of the problem and is going to allow his country to be used as a transit point for illegal activity.

I know that diplomatic relations between Australia and Indonesia are somewhat strained at the moment because of events around the place, but that is not to say that we have not got to keep trying with them. The report this morning indicated that the Foreign Minister, Mr Downer, would be going to Indonesia next month and that President Wahid said he would meet him and that this matter would probably be up for discussion. That is welcome, but it is not enough. It is certainly not enough on the basis of his earlier remarks referring to people-smuggling and the fact that their transit through his nation was not his concern but Australia's.

We have to go further: not only has Mr Ruddock got to make early plans to go to Indonesia but also our Prime Minister has to make those plans and go up there and get every diplomatic movement put in place to assist us on this. There was—and it has been recognised—great cooperation between the two nations during the course of the Vietnamese boat people experience, and there was cooperation with the introduction of a comprehensive UNHCR plan of action to deal with the problem of Vietnamese boat people in the past. It can be done and it has to be done again. Indeed it will be done again, because Australia is the end of the chain, and we are the ones that have to be proactive in getting that cooperation up and moving yet again.

I will conclude my remarks by welcoming the cooperation from around this place for the passage of the bill. I again put on the record that the Australian Labor Party, the opposition in this place, made an enormous contribution to the details contained in the bill, and I hope that can be seen as a message that there can be a bipartisan approach to dealing with this difficulty. Certainly, we have to play politics across the chamber from time to time. But when we are acting for the good of Australia, sometimes the bipartisan approach is a better way of dealing with a problem than the scoring of a few cheap political points that may or may not be reflected in the polls.

talk.start.para: —I was not going to speak in this second reading debate because I did not think it would serve any use whatsoever. I did not know that Senator Cooney would be speaking in this debate but I heard some of what he said. It is extremely important that some of the issues that he raised are considered—particularly by the Labor Party. Where it is going in all of these matters one will never know. It seems that, at this particular stage, fear is one of the emotions that appear to be influencing policy outcomes on this matter.

speech.para: I apologise that I was not here for Senator Bartlett's speech. I would have liked to have heard his speech but, unfortunately, as we all know in this place, we have got an enormous number of other commitments. Before I came into the chamber I heard Senator McKiernan allege that I had accused him of creating a division between those who come in by boats and those who are processed through the UNHCR system. I invite any honourable member to have a look at what Senator McKiernan said yesterday. I defy any honourable member to suggest otherwise than that he was actually establishing a division between those two groups of people.

You are making an assumption that persons who come in by boat have less of a claim to the protection of Australia than those who come in by other means, through the UNHCR system. That is not what we should be all about. We should be providing a system which will enable a proper judgment to be made as to the protection of their basic human rights. I thought that was what the whole process was supposed to be about. But what we had yesterday was a situation whereby a temporary visa is given to some, whereas others—for example those who bought their passage to Australia, coming out here very comfortably in aircraft—do not need to go through that situation. They are not given the three-year temporary visa.

Now it appears to come down to whether people have paid money to get here. I come back to the point that I made yesterday. What about all of those people who got here in modern aircraft—they took a taxi to the airport and boarded an aircraft—because they had papers? Honourable senators will realise that many persons who are trying to escape persecution in dictatorial countries are not able to get travel documents. There is no use going over this time and time again.
I was very interested in an article in The Australian this morning by The Australian's political editor, Mr Shanahan, and I believe it is worth quoting from. It reads:
AUSTRALIA is under siege from criminally manipulated, disease-carrying, job-stealing, tax-avoiding, illegal economic refugees arriving by boat in northern Australia.

Waves of these illegal aliens are threatening the fabric of our society to such an extent the Federal Parliament is introducing draconian laws to impose longer jail sentences on the crews of these ill-fated fishing vessels than applied to some of Australia's most notorious rapist-murderers.

Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock has described the fight against boat people as "a high priority for the Government" which is both "urgent and ongoing". He's visited China and Thailand to spread the word and Australia's harried ambassador to Jakarta, John McCarthy, in the middle of a diplomatic disaster, has been given "a high priority" task to combat boat people using Indonesia as a corridor.
The Labor Party has concurred with the Government's rhetoric and tough measures to show politicians are "doing something" to protect health and jobs.
Yet all of this energy and hysteria is directed towards a pitifully few, albeit increasing, number of boat people.
Then he goes into the number of arrivals:
In 1997-98 there were 157 boat people arrivals, in 1998-99 there were 921 and so far in this financial year there have been 1789. That's 2867 boat people in the past three years.
This "flood" is mostly East Asians but an increasing number of people are being smuggled from India, Pakistan, Afghanistan, Iran and Iraq.
But, as he says:

Now consider this: last year, in just 12 months there were 12,890 illegal immigrants who broke the law, stole jobs, didn't pay tax, could have been carrying diseases, jumped refugee queues, were definitely economic refugees and some of whom will stay forever.
These illegals outnumber the boatpeople by more than six to one, even with the recent rise in the rate of boat arrivals, and are not an obvious wave but an insidious rising tide.

If caught they face "forced departure", taxpayer-funded return airfares, and are refused entry to Australia for three years. Why no outcry? Why no draconian laws? Where's the top-priority ministerial trips to the countries of origin?

I raised this yesterday and I raised it in a committee meeting on Monday. I asked how many illegals were in Australia. There are 52,000, and most are British. As the political editor of the Australian goes on:

The explanation may be that these illegals are the plane people—they simply arrive on a nice shiny jumbo from a background comfortable enough to have proper passports, visas and money for an airfare and walk through Customs to melt into Australian society.

Most of them come from the UK and the US. There are currently at least 50,000 illegal "plane people" in Australia who are working, not paying tax, claiming social security and using taxpayer-funded health and other services.

And one quarter of them, more than 12,000, have been in Australia for nine years or more, comfortably settled into society after never having to face an immigration examination or sit in a queue anywhere.

Surely, if the Government's concerns are to remove people in Australia on an unlawful basis because of criminality or because they threaten Australian jobs, avoid tax and use services, then the biggest group should be the priority.
Of course, the Government has to juggle more than one ball at a time and fighting the perpetrators of people-smuggling and trying to ensure refugees are brought to Australia properly are correct.
Shanahan obviously says that the government is correct in that task of trying to clamp down on people smuggling. He continues:
But the undue emphasis on the smaller category of boat people smacks of discrimination.
Later in his article he says:

And since we know, from Immigration Department apprehensions, that between 15 and 20 per cent of visa overstayers admit to working, it is reasonable to assume that some of them fall victim to extortionists and tax avoiders in the labour market just as boat people do.
How many are carrying unchecked diseases and may make demands on our health system?

Yet, while there are more than 10,000 British and American visa overstayers in Australia and only 3000 Indonesians, the next highest category, the largest number detected and returned comes from Indonesia. Americans detected don't even rate in the top 10.

All of this begs two questions: Why aren't we concentrating on well-heeled illegals from Britain and America and, if 60,000 illegal plane people can be absorbed without destroying the fabric of our society, why can't we do the same for less than 3000 boat people?

I thought I would read that into Hansard in full, but there were a couple of paragraphs that I did not. This was the article in the Opinion page of today's Australian newspaper. I think that the government has something to answer for. Why is it whipping up this hysteria amongst the public? And it is hysteria; you need only speak to people about it. When you explain the situation to them, they say, `Oh, we had not thought about it along that line.' The unfortunate part about it is fear makes bad policy. This policy is generated by an irrational fear, and is bad policy.

talk.start.para: —I thank honourable senators for their contribution to the second reading debate on the Border Protection Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 . I have a number of comments I would like to make on what people have said. It is clear that people seeking a migration outcome in a developed country have identified Australia as a target. Numbers of people arriving without authorisation by boat and by air are at record levels. Despite what Senator Harradine and Senator Cooney have said, we have seen an unprecedented increase in the number of people who are arriving.

speech.para: I will just go back through some figures. In 1989-90, there were 224; in 1990-91, 158; in 1991-92, 78; in 1992-93, 194; in 1993-94, 194; 1994-95, 1,071; in 1995-96, 589; in 1996-97, 365; in 1997-98, 157; and, in 1998-99, 926. In the first 4½ months of this year, we have seen 1,814, and it is increasing each month. As I have been advised, we have not even seen the numbers coming possibly from China with the seasonal arrival that we get from there.

Senator Schacht said yesterday that we were doing nothing and that the minister needed to go to China. Senator Schacht needs to catch up. If he was interested in the area, he would demonstrate an interest and maybe check the Internet or look at some press releases. Mr Ruddock issued a press release indicating that he had been to China and what he had done there to try to involve China in assisting us, and there has been cooperation at that level. I think the minister had been there before that and the First Secretary to the department was there addressing that issue. There have been various measures put in place to try to address the issue either in source countries or in transit countries through diplomatic efforts, through increasing compliance officers and through various other diplomatic measures.

So for people to come in here and say that we are doing nothing other than something about the borders is totally untrue and does not give credit to the enormous effort that DFAT officers are putting in and the enormous effort that the minister personally and his staff are putting in—travelling long distances overseas in very short timeframes—to address this issue. Credit should be given where credit is due. To say that nothing else is being done is unacceptable.

The government has also responded in five areas to this unprecedented increase. We have seen changes to coastal surveillance and detection; the prosecution of people smugglers, the seizing of their boats and the increasing of penalties for that. We have an international information strategy directed at both the smugglers and those they seek to exploit. We are addressing the factors that encourage those who select Australia as a target, and we are working internationally, as I just mentioned, with the UNHCR, the IOM, the countries of first asylum, the transit countries and other destination countries to generate cooperative action against people smuggling and durable protection solutions.

Senator McKiernan has indicated that it is not just a problem for Australia, and I commend his approach to this. It is not just a problem for Australia; it is a problem for the world. It is a problem that has to be dealt with on an international front, and that is another area in which Australia has a responsibility, and it is working towards that.

The last thing people want to do is leave the country of their birth not by choice. Some people, like Senator McKiernan, choose to leave. When I visit his country I sometimes think it is a beautiful country, but I can see why he chose Australia. But to be forced to leave your country must be one of the worst things that can happen to you. It behoves the international community to work assiduously and tirelessly to reduce the problem at the source, because many of those people do not want to actually leave their countries.

This bill will give our officers new powers to board, search and detain vessels in international waters that they suspect are involved in people smuggling. At the moment, our officers are constrained by the 12-mile rule, which means they are unable to investigate any vessel that lies beyond our own territorial waters. This year alone we have seen at least three Chinese vessels attempt to exploit this loophole in our border policing. They have used a new modus operandi and been able to avoid detection by sailing through international waters east of Papua New Guinea and staying in international waters while waiting for speedboats to arrive to ferry their human cargo ashore before returning to China. The new legislation will allow us to crack down on increasingly sophisticated people smugglers like these by ensuring they are not beyond the reach of Australian domestic law.

Other powers in the bill include detention, forfeiture, seizure and disposal of ships and aircraft used in people smuggling operations. Vessels found to be unseaworthy, a risk to safety or navigation or a threat to the environment will be removed and destroyed appropriately in accordance with the environment protection act. To ensure the safety of officers, changes to the Customs Act will allow Customs officers to carry and use approved firearms and other approved items of personal defence equipment in certain circumstances for personal defence. The government has responded quickly and unequivocally to the growing criminal activity of people smuggling, and this bill will further enhance Australia's ability to combat people smuggling.

Senator Cooney asked questions about the training of the Customs officers. The Customs officers will be trained by the Australian Federal Police in the use of the firearms under the rules, regulations and training that the Australian Federal Police use. There will be a six-week training course for initial certification and then two to three days per annum for re-certification. As I said, it is the same training given to the AFP.

Senator Bartlett in his speech talked about fishery officers having the same powers to use firearms. Under the federal Fisheries Management Act, fishery officers do not have the power to use firearms, but Customs officers who are exercising the powers as fishery officers will be able to use these powers but will be trained because they are Customs officers, as I just mentioned in response to the question that Senator Cooney raised. Hopefully that clarifies that issue.

Senator Cooney mentioned Mr Gerry Hand and his views about people queue jumping. It was a comment that Mr Hand made in 1992. Senator Cooney commented on his ability as a minister. Mr Hand has kept abreast of these issues and is on the External Reference Committee appointed by Minister Ruddock. He has looked at these matters very carefully, and he has said:

I would urge everyone in Parliament to support this, because if they don't they will be giving succour to international people smugglers. There is a right way to come here and a wrong way, and unless we do something, the situation will just run wild.

He also indicated—and I cannot remember the exact quote—that it is the minister who ought to be in the driving seat controlling the immigration program, not the people smugglers. That indicates that Mr Hand has responded to the current situation where some people have not been accepted by the UNHCR as refugees. Some may have applied, and—as Senator McKiernan said—because they have the assets to pay people smugglers, they have been able to speed up the process. But those who do not have those assets or connections can lie languishing, waiting to be accepted through the UNHCR and then the Australian resettlement process.

It is not fair to say that the government is just being alarmist. Some people have accused the Labor Party of being alarmist as well. There is a significant increase in people smuggling. There is a significant increase in the number of people who are coming to Australia through this method. Australia needs to do something to protect its borders and to send a message that there are methods of coming here and of being resettled in Australia. Australia is one of the most generous countries in the world.

I will not take issue with some of the things Senator Bartlett said, but, Senator Bartlett, the department and the minister would be prepared to give you a briefing just on those figures you used last night, comparing Australia with Canada. We are not comparing apples with apples, and we should get those figures straight. But I will not go on with that today. It is difficult to compare the figures, because you are comparing onshore with offshore, and in some countries people are not given permanent resettlement. Australia has a permanent resettlement program. It also has one of the most effective resettlement assistance programs, and other countries visit us to see how we do that.

We need to be making sure that we are comparing apples with apples. We are comparing onshore with offshore; we are comparing those people who have got permanent residency with those people who have been given temporary residency in other countries. We need to get those figures and look at them carefully. The sorts of figures that Senator Bartlett was bandying around yesterday were not quite correct. I commend the bill to the chamber. I thank Senator McKiernan, who indicated that we need a bipartisan approach on this particularly difficult issue.

I accept the comment that Senator Cooney made—that Minister Ruddock has a very lonely life. I have likened the responsibility that an immigration minister has to the wisdom of Solomon to the power of a million. You have to cut the baby into many parts, and it is a very difficult and onerous task. For someone who is compassionate and has the best interests of these people at heart—and has always had, since he has been in parliament—it is a very difficult call. I appreciate the bipartisan support; I appreciate the support of senators who have indicated they will be supporting the bill.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Bartlett's ) be agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I would like to table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendment to be moved to the bill—this memorandum was circulated in the chamber on 24 November 1999—and I move government amendment (1):

speech.para: (1) Schedule 1, page 45 (after line 4), at the end of the Schedule, add:
Add:

(3) Australia is taken not to have protection obligations to a non-citizen who has not taken all possible steps to avail himself or herself of a right to enter and reside in, whether temporarily or permanently and however that right arose or is expressed, any country apart from Australia, including countries of which the non-citizen is a national.

(4) However, if the non-citizen has a well-founded fear of being persecuted in a country for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion, subsection (3) does not apply in relation to that country.
(5) Also, if the non-citizen has a well-founded fear that:
(a) a country will return the non-citizen to another country; and
(b) the non-citizen will be persecuted in that other country for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion;
subsection (3) does not apply in relation to the first-mentioned country.
(6) For the purposes of subsection (3), the question of whether a non-citizen is a national of a particular country must be determined solely by reference to the law of that country.
(7) Subsection (6) does not, by implication, affect the interpretation of any other provision of this Act.
After "91K (temporary safe haven visa),", insert "91P (non-citizens with access to protection from third countries),".

para.inline: 67 After Subdivision AJ of Division 3 of Part 2

speech.para: Insert:

para.inline: Subdivision AK—Non-citizens with access to protection from third countries

speech.para: This Subdivision is enacted because the Parliament considers that a non-citizen who can avail himself or herself of protection from a third country, because of nationality or some other right to re-enter and reside in the third country, should seek protection from the third country instead of applying in Australia for a protection visa, or, in some cases, any other visa. Any such non-citizen who is an unlawful non-citizen will be subject to removal under Division 8.
Note: For protection visas, see section 36.

para.inline: 91N Non-citizens to whom this Subdivision applies

speech.para: (1) This Subdivision applies to a non-citizen at a particular time if, at that time, the non-citizen is a national of 2 or more countries.
(2) This Subdivision also applies to a non-citizen at a particular time if, at that time:
(a) the non-citizen has a right to re-enter and reside in, whether temporarily or permanently and however that right arose or is expressed, any country (the available country) apart from:
(i) Australia; or
(ii) a country of which the non-citizen is a national; or
(iii) if the non-citizen has no country of nationality—the country of which the non-citizen is an habitual resident; and

(b) the non-citizen has ever resided in the available country for a continuous period of at least 7 days or, if the regulations prescribe a longer continuous period, for at least that longer period; and
(c) a declaration by the Minister is in effect under subsection (3) in relation to the available country.
(3) The Minister may, after considering any advice received from the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees:
(a) declare in writing that a specified country:
(i) provides access, for persons seeking asylum, to effective procedures for assessing their need for protection; and
(ii) provides protection to persons to whom that country has protection obligations; and
(iii) meets relevant human rights standards for persons to whom that country has protection obligations; or
(b) in writing, revoke a declaration made under paragraph (a).
(4) A declaration made under paragraph (3)(a):
(a) takes effect when it is made by the Minister; and
(b) ceases to be in effect if and when it is revoked by the Minister under paragraph (3)(b).

(5) The Minister must cause a copy of a declaration, or of a revocation of a declaration, to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 2 sitting days of that House after the Minister makes the declaration or revokes the declaration.
(6) For the purposes of this section, the question of whether a non-citizen is a national of a particular country must be determined solely by reference to the law of that country.
(7) Subsection (6) does not, by implication, affect the interpretation of any other provision of this Act.

para.inline: 91P Non-citizens to whom this Subdivision applies are unable to make valid applications for certain visas

speech.para: (1) Despite any other provision of this Act but subject to section 91Q, if:
(a) this Subdivision applies to a non-citizen at a particular time; and
(b) at that time, the non-citizen applies, or purports to apply, for a visa; and
(c) the non-citizen is in the migration zone and has not been immigration cleared at that time;
neither that application, nor any other application the non-citizen makes for a visa while he or she remains in the migration zone, is a valid application.
(2) Despite any other provision of this Act but subject to section 91Q, if:
(a) this Subdivision applies to a non-citizen at a particular time; and
(b) at that time, the non-citizen applies, or purports to apply, for a protection visa; and
(c) the non-citizen is in the migration zone and has been immigration cleared at that time;
neither that application, nor any other application made by the non-citizen for a protection visa while he or she remains in the migration zone, is a valid application.

para.inline: 91Q Minister may determine that section 91P does not apply to a non-citizen

speech.para: (1) If the Minister thinks that it is in the public interest to do so, the Minister may, by written notice given to a particular non-citizen, determine that section 91P does not apply to an application for a visa made by the non-citizen in the period starting when the notice is given and ending at the end of the seventh working day after the day that the notice is given.

(2) For the purposes of subsection (1), the matters that the Minister may consider include information that raises the possibility that, although the non-citizen satisfies the description set out in subsection 91N(1) or (2), the non-citizen might not be able to avail himself or herself of protection from the country, or any of the countries, by reference to which the non-citizen satisfies that description.
(3) The power under subsection (1) may only be exercised by the Minister personally.
(4) If the Minister makes a determination under subsection (1), he or she is to cause to be laid before each House of the Parliament a statement that:
(a) sets out the determination; and
(b) sets out the reasons for the determination, referring in particular to the Minister's reasons for thinking that his or her actions are in the public interest.
(5) A statement under subsection (4) is not to include:
(a) the name of the non-citizen; or
(b) any information that may identify the non-citizen; or

(c) if the Minister thinks that it would not be in the public interest to publish the name of another person connected in any way with the matter concerned—the name of that other person or any information that may identify that other person.
(6) A statement under subsection (4) is to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after:
(a) if the determination is made between 1 January and 30 June (inclusive) in a year—1 July in that year; or
(b) if the determination is made between 1 July and 31 December (inclusive) in a year—1 January in the following year.

(7) The Minister does not have a duty to consider whether to exercise the power under subsection (1) in respect of any non-citizen, whether he or she is requested to do so by the non-citizen or by any other person, or in any other circumstances.
Add:
(9) An officer must remove as soon as reasonably practicable an unlawful non-citizen if:
(a) the non-citizen is a detainee; and
(b) Subdivision AK of Division 3 of this Part applies to the non-citizen; and
(c) either:
(i) the non-citizen has not been immigration cleared; or
(ii) the non-citizen has not made a valid application for a substantive visa that can be granted when the applicant is in the migration zone; and
(d) either:
(i) the Minister has not given a notice under subsection 91Q(1) to the non-citizen; or

(ii) the Minister has given such a notice but the period mentioned in that subsection has ended and the non-citizen has not, during that period, made a valid application for a substantive visa that can be granted when the applicant is in the migration zone.

I would like to put on the record the government's appreciation for the cooperation received from the opposition on this matter. In particular, the government would like to acknowledge the efforts of the member for Denison, Mr Duncan Kerr, and his staff for their input in formulating the amendment and willingness to address the serious issues surrounding this amendment in a cooperative manner. Senator McKiernan indicated the importance of a bipartisan approach on an issue of such importance to Australia. I also want to place on the record that the government has an unequivocal and continuing commitment to not either directly or indirectly refoule a refugee.

I also have a tabling speech, which I have circulated to the opposition, the Democrats, Senator Harradine, Senator Harris and Senator Brown, and I seek leave to incorporate this document into Hansard.
Leave granted.
On behalf of the government, I would like to move amendments to the Border Protection Legislation Amendment Bill 1999.
The amendments that I place before the chamber today are part of a package of tough new measures that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs announced on the 13th of October 1999.
These measures are aimed at curbing the growing number of people arriving illegally in Australia, often through people smuggling operations.
The Refugees Convention and Protocol have, from inception, been intended to provide asylum for refugees with no other country to turn to.
Increasingly, however, it has been observed that asylum seekers are taking advantage of the convention's arrangements.
Some refugee claimants may be nationals of more than one country, or have rights of return or entry to another country, where they would be protected against persecution.

Such people attempt to use the refugee process as a means of obtaining residence in the country of their choice, without taking reasonable steps to avail themselves of protection which might already be available to them elsewhere.
This practice, widely referred to as "forum shopping", represents an increasing problem faced by Australia and other countries viewed as desirable migration destinations .
It also imposes unnecessary costs on the taxpayer and represents an often organised attempt to subvert immigration and border controls.
But most importantly, it directly undercuts the ability of countries, such as Australia, to offer international resettlement to people on a needs basis.
Domestic case law has generally re-inforced the principle that Australia does not owe protection obligations under the refugees convention, to those who have protection in other countries.
It has also developed the principle that pre-existing avenues for protection should be ruled out before a person's claim to refugee status in Australia is considered.
Under current arrangements the question of whether a person has protection in another country can only be considered as part of the decision-making process for a protection visa application.
This increases the time and cost associated with reaching a decision and, for unsuccessful applicants, opens up the right to seek administrative review
For unauthorised arrivals, it extends the period of time that they are detained and adds to the current pressure on our detention centres.

For those who have a right of re-entry to a safe third country, it also raises the risk that, by the time the application has been finally determined, and avenues for judicial review have been exhausted, their rights of re-entry will have expired.
This has occurred in a number of recent cases, with the result that Australia was found to owe protection obligations to people who had voluntarily forsaken countries of first asylum.

The amendments will introduce into the Migration Act a new subdivision which will apply to non-citizens who are dual or multiple nationals, or who have a right to re-enter and reside in a third country.

A statutory bar will prevent such non-citizens while onshore from making a valid application for a protection visa if they have been immigration cleared, or, if they have not been immigration cleared, from making a valid application for any visa.
The statutory bar will be accompanied by discretionary provisions for ministerial intervention to lift the bar in the public interest.

In conjunction with ministerial guidelines to provide guidance to departmental staff on cases that are to be brought to the minister's attention, this will ensure that Australia meets its protection obligations.
This will ensure that where a person may not have protection in a third country, the statutory bar would be lifted to allow them to make an application.

The amendments also include an interpretative provision to make it clear that Australia does not owe protection obligations to non-citizens if they have not taken all possible steps to avail themselves of a right to enter and reside in a country other than Australia.

However, this will not apply in relation to countries in respect of which non-citizens have a well-founded fear of being persecuted, or of being returned to another country in which they may be persecuted.

Finally, these amendments insert a definition of "nationality" into the Migration Act, to make it clear that nationality or citizenship is to be determined solely by reference to the domestic law of the country in question.
These measures will ensure that only those who most need our assistance—those with no other country to turn to are able to enter our protection system.
The amendments in no way diminish the government's commitment to the refugees convention, and to providing humanitarian assistance to those most in need.
Indeed they work to support the fundamental framework of protection for refugees in the face of increasingly sophisticated attempts by smugglers and "forum shoppers" to exploit this framework.
I understand that the opposition shares our concern to combat the surge in people smuggling and abuse of the protection system.
look to them to support these necessary measures against exploitation of Australia's generous refugee protection arrangements.
I ask that all non-government parties allow the passage of these amendments
I commend the amendments to the chamber.

talk.start.para: —Earlier this morning I circulated a couple of proposed amendments to the government amendment, but I will not move these straightaway. I want to ask the parliamentary secretary some questions first, which may obviate the need for me to move them. I think it is important to examine fairly closely the actual content of the amendment and get on the record from the parliamentary secretary and the government exactly how it will work and what the legislative intent is, et cetera.

speech.para: When you are dealing with protection obligations and particularly amendments that seek to constrain, or put in place definitions that may be perceived to be constraining, the implementation of protection obligations, then it is very important to get as clear as possible what the intent is of them. I am sure that all members of this chamber would be very keen to ensure that we did not inadvertently support something that was going to lead to Australia being in a position where we refoule someone, because refoulement is obviously the fundamental component of our protection obligations to prevent that from happening and to prevent Australia from being a party to sending somebody back to face persecution, torture or death.

Let me say at the start with respect to the Border Protection Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 , which is actually about quite a lot of different matters, that the Democrats are willing to give support to measures which we believe will constructively assist in tackling people smuggling or address issues that need an appropriate response to the worldwide problem. My contributions on this issue yesterday and today have emphasised that this is a problem around the world and a bigger problem in many other countries than it is in Australia. But it is one that Australia is linked into, and I think it is not inappropriate for us to examine how best we fit into the enactment of our obligations under the refugee convention.

The minister's tabling speech in relation to the amendments, as well as the explanatory memorandum, his statements and his original press release, I have gone through. I think the basic principle that the minister has indicated, which is what these amendments are reputedly meant to be about, is ensuring that people who have nationality of more than one country or have protection rights in a third country should take those up. I and the Democrats do not have a problem with that in principle. We need to try to ensure that countries around the world share the load of the huge problem of the number of people seeking protection. The Democrats are quite willing to support the principle that other countries share the load equitably and that people who have protection or citizenship in a safe country should be required to take that up rather than jump across to Australia and engage protection obligations here. That principle is fine. What I would like to have clarified from the government is how these amendments will operate.
I will go through the tabling speech from the parliamentary secretary. One paragraph reads:
Some refugee claimants may be nationals of more than one country, or have rights of return or entry to another country, where they would be protected against prosecution.
In the very next paragraph, the parliament secretary says:

Such people attempt to use the refugee process as a means of obtaining residence in the country of their choice, without taking reasonable steps to avail themselves of protection which might already be available to them elsewhere.

I think that word `might' is a fairly important one, as well as the word `would' in the paragraph above. What we need to ensure, if we are going to uphold our obligations, in my view, is that people do already have protection available to them or will clearly have protection available to them, not that they might—because they might or they might not. If we are going to send them somewhere where they do not, then we will be potentially a party to their being refouled, in my view. That is something that we should not be a party to.
A few paragraphs further down the tabled speech says:
Domestic case law has generally re-inforced the principle that Australia does not owe protection obligations . . . to those who have protection in other countries.
And that is quite unequivocal: people who have protection, not people who might have protection. Another paragraph further down reads:
Under current arrangements, the question of whether a person has protection in another country can only be considered as part of the decision-making process for a protection visa application.

These amendments seek to change that, but surely the question is still there: does a person have protection in another country? These amendments prevent people, if they are seen as having protection in another country, from being able to make a valid application. Basically their application is not received, as I read it. In that case, I would like an indication from the government about how that question will be determined. If we are not going to receive people's applications, how are we going to clearly and confidently determine that people do have protection in another country? I think that needs to be spelt out clearly because it is not clear to me. Further down, the tabled speech reads:
The amendments will introduce into the Migration Act a new subdivision which will apply to non-citizens who . . . have a right to re-enter and reside in a third country.

Again, re-entering and residing is very different from having protection. They may be able to reside but for how long are they able to reside? Are they able to reside for a week before they get forcibly removed and deported to yet another country? Or will they be able to reside for as long as they choose under the protection of that country? That needs to be made very clear as well.

The amendments contain a provision which is becoming quite common in the Migration Act now and which gives the minister discretion to intervene and lift the statutory bar on people being able to submit an application for a protection visa. That is seen as the safeguard. The next paragraph says:

In conjunction with ministerial guidelines to provide guidance to departmental staff on cases that are to be brought to the minister's attention, this will ensure that Australia meets its protection obligations.

It is specifically saying that this discretionary provision for ministerial intervention is there to ensure that Australia meets its protection obligations. Two questions come out of that: firstly, if we are not going to receive the person's application in a legal sense, then, again, how does it get into the system that departmental staff are considering their situation anyway? I am sure there is a system, but I would like to have it clarified.

Perhaps, more importantly, as with many other components in the act where the minister has discretion to intervene, he cannot be compelled to intervene—there is no compulsion, it is a non-compellable discretion. How can a non-compellable discretion be a mechanism that can ensure that something has happened if there is no way that a minister can be pressured to ensure an outcome? It is totally in the minister's hands. I am sure the government will say, `This minister is top stuff. He knows what he is doing. He will not get it wrong.' They may be right. But who knows whether a future minister in a future government of whatever party will be as competent.

I would like clarification of how a non-compellable provision, a non-compellable power, can be seen as something that will ensure that Australia meets its protection outcomes, and how the fact that that discretionary provision exists at all can be seen to be part of ensuring that we meet our protection obligations. When I first saw that provision I thought it was more. As it says in the parliamentary secretary's tabling speech, it is `in the public interest'. The minister may think it is in the public interest. He may have humanitarian grounds or broader compassionate grounds to want to lift the bar on people applying. That is very different from lifting the bar to ensure that we meet our protection obligations.

I know I am reeling off a lot of questions at once, but I am trying to get as many of them out of the way as I can. Again, at this stage I am just working from the parliamentary secretary's tabling speech and interconnecting that with bits in the explanatory memorandum and the amendments. I have two questions relating to the statement in that speech that `Australia does not owe protection obligations to non-citizens if they have not taken all possible steps to avail themselves of a right to enter and reside in a country other than Australia'. The first question goes to the issue of whether entering and residing equates to receiving protection under the refugee convention or whether it just means they will be let in for a while and what happens to them after that is some other country's problem, not ours.

The second question goes to the issue of taking `all possible steps to avail themselves of a right to enter'. If someone has to take `all possible steps to avail themselves of a right to enter and reside' in another country, depending on your definition of `reside' in another country, that could be read to mean—and I imagine this is not the intent—that they have to make application for visitor visas to every other country on the planet before Australia to follow all possible steps to see whether or not they have a `right to enter and reside in a country other than Australia'. That is perhaps an extreme interpretation. But I think it would be helpful to get on the record from the government that that is not the meaning of that relevant section within the amendment, that `all possible steps' does not mean we are last in the queue, if you like, and people have to go to every other country on the planet before they can apply in Australia. They are some initial questions which I seek clarification from the government on.

talk.start.para: —Senator Bartlett has gone through the tabling speech that I incorporated into Hansard . I think to go through that statement word by word as if that is the actual legislation is not helpful. When I said, `Such people attempt to use the refugee process as a means of obtaining residence in the country of their choice, without taking reasonable steps to avail themselves of protection which might already be available,' that is in the sense that we are talking about a large group of people, a generic group of people. Some might have protection in another country; some may not have protection in another country. That is why the word `might' is used there: we are talking about a group of people—some might have protection and some might not.

speech.para: You asked how people get into the system so the minister can actually exercise his power to lift the bar. Well, they attempt to make an application. The department does not throw the application in the bin. It actually has to go through the application and assess it, and that process of assessing it can indicate that the only way this person could be considered further is for the minister to lift the bar. So that is in response to that issue.

You asked how we know what ministers will do in the future. We give various powers to ministers and we put those powers in acts. If ministers abuse those powers, then I suppose the legislation has to be reviewed. But in piece after piece of legislation we pass here ministers are given various powers to do various things. I am sure if the minister were not using his power appropriately the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees would also respond. Further to your question, I have been advised that ministers are officers of the Crown and are charged to act in the public interest.

I have tried to deal with all your questions. There were a series of them, Senator Bartlett. If you do not think I have dealt with them, then can you quickly and succinctly reiterate those that you do not think I have dealt with?

talk.start.para: —I will do that. Perhaps I will go to the actual wording of the amendments rather than to the speech. My understanding is that the contents of speeches, particularly ministerial speeches, do have some importance in terms of what they may imply. So I thought that was where I would start.

speech.para: It might seem like nitpicking about words, but words are what end up in the law, and it is the words in the law that end up being interpreted by the courts. So I think the words are fairly important. A question I asked towards the end concerned the first part of your amendment. Paragraph (3) of item 65 reads:

Australia is taken not to have protection obligations to a non-citizen who has not taken all possible steps to avail himself or herself of a right to enter and reside in, whether temporarily or permanently—

a third country basically, to use the shorthand. Firstly, I acknowledge this may be an extreme interpretation but I would like to get an interpretation from the government about this phrase `all possible steps to avail himself or herself of a right to enter and reside in'. I hope it does not mean that they have to apply to enter every other country other than Australia. Secondly, and perhaps more importantly, together with `enter and reside in' go the words `whether temporarily or permanently'. I would have thought that being able to reside somewhere, particularly temporarily, was not the same as having a protection obligation from that country.

I thought I heard in the statements from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Ruddock, about this measure that those countries would have to be ones that were signatories to the refugee convention, so people already had a right to enter them and then they could seek to get their protection obligations assessed by that third country. But I might be misquoting him.

I can see that as making some sense because at least it requires that third country to be one that is a signatory to the convention and will test their protection entitlements. However, I do not see that in this amendment and that causes me concern because, firstly, we are putting a very broad provision on what people have to do before we will even look at their application or accept it as valid. Secondly, if we are not even going to accept an application as valid if people can stay somewhere else temporarily, that seems to me to fall far short of someone who has engaged the protection obligations of a third country. That was my understanding of the main intent of what the forum shopping problem was about.

I emphasise that I am not doing this to make life difficult for the government. The Democrats support the principle that a person has a right to go to third countries whether as a citizen or as a person having protection obligations. But I am concerned that we do not pass something that goes way beyond that principle or, at least if we do so, it should be made very clear that that is what we are doing. And if that is what we are doing, then I think the Democrats would have a bit more trouble supporting it.

talk.start.para: —Senator Bartlett, again I would suggest to you that it would be very helpful in this debate if you would like to sit down at some stage—I think I could benefit, too, because I am still on a steep learning curve in this area—and have a briefing from the department on this issue to clarify some of the questions you have asked.

speech.para: I have been advised that it is not that we expect people to apply to every country that is a signatory to the convention before they can apply here; it is if they have an existing right to enter a country. I have been advised there are some countries that are signatories to the convention where we would not expect them to exercise that right because of the human rights record of that country. However, there are some people who have an existing right to go to a country that would protect them but, when they are advised by our posts to go and apply for a visa, they refuse to do so. In that situation, we expect them to use that right first before applying to Australia. That is what that means—I will check I have said the right thing—for onshore applicants, if I can just qualify that.

talk.start.para: —I rise very briefly to draw Senator Bartlett's attention to the government amendments. I make the point that I do not think his series of questions were nitpicking, because this is the proper avenue to ask those questions and to seek a clarification of what the amendments mean. I draw his attention to the provisions contained both in proposed section 91N(3) and in the whole of proposed section 91Q. Senator Bartlett would be aware that the non-compellable ministerial discretion appears in a number of areas throughout the act. It is a particularly important provision dealing with the matters that we are discussing in this particular instance.

speech.para: If Senator Bartlett examines the content of 91Q—it was an initiative of the opposition in the dialogue and discussion that went on between our offices, the minister's office and departmental officers—he will see the extension that has been put on the ministerial discretion in that provision. I ask Senator Bartlett to take that into consideration as well as those provisions contained in 91N(3) which deal with advice from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. These are savings devices inserted into the amendments, which we on this side of the chamber are happy with at this point in time. I trust that, now it has been pointed out to Senator Bartlett, that will satisfy the Democrats' concerns.

talk.start.para: —I follow on from what Senator McKiernan and Senator Bartlett said. Senator Patterson told Senator Bartlett to look at the legislation rather than the second reading speech. The second reading speech has led to a lot of difficulty that it should not have. The second reading speech does not address the legislation. This legislation, if you look at it, is mainly about the detection of crime, the apprehension or even arrest of suspects and detention. It is about powers of stopping ships inside and outside Australian waters and on the high seas. It then goes into the fisheries and what have you.

speech.para: The contents mention chasing and boarding ships and aircraft. That is a policing procedure. Forfeiture is a matter of process, if you like, where, in certain circumstances, you forfeit what you have. The enforcement visa comes somewhere near the Migration Act. There are amendments relating to fish stock agreements and technical amendments. Schedule 2 of the Customs Act deals with chasing and boarding ships and aircraft. Part 2 deals with the transfer of goods into and out of coasting trade. Schedule 3 deals with the Fisheries Management Act 1991. Customs officers are to be fisheries officers. It then deals with suspected illegal foreign fishers. It all has to do with process.

The second reading speech seeks to justify a change in process and an increase in policing powers by saying that it was disturbing to hear reports of some of those arrivals asking for Pert shampoo immediately upon their arrival. I am not terribly sure what someone asking for Pert shampoo has to do with due process. When you say that Senator Bartlett should not look at the second reading speech, you are absolutely right. This has been a very interesting debate, because it is a debate that has at no stage addressed the issues contained in the legislation. It has contained all sorts of things about migrants, snake heads and whether they come from Iraq or Afghanistan or what have you. What has that to do with the process of hot pursuit? What has it to do with whether you can board a boat? What has it to do with the fact that you do not have to ask for a warrant?

We are talking about the processes that can be used against Australian citizens—Australian boats are concerned—and foreigners on the high seas. It is also about the use of weapons by customs officers. It is about all those sorts of things, none of which have been addressed. I am afraid that there is a lot of merit in what Senator Harradine said before, when he said that you use an emotional argument to achieve a purpose. It is a classic process in the courts. You try to get some more power by saying that there is a rash of paedophilia, there are murders being committed or there is a rash of burglary. I am so old now, unfortunately, that I remember these various campaigns over the years.

This is just another campaign. I am not saying that it is not justified; I am voting for the measures. However, why can we not get to the point where we address the issues involved rather than go through a second reading speech which does not address due process but which tries to create an emotional flood so that we put up our hands for anything that anybody wants to suggest? Why should a person about to board a boat not have to get a warrant by telecommunications centres? Is six weeks training for customs officers in firearms sufficient? It is not simply about being able to use the arms; it is about having them in a way which is not likely to create an international incident with the United States or somebody else. That is what we should be addressing.

In the old days, when I was young—that is how long ago it was—the police did not even carry revolvers. They do now because things have changed. But the police are trained not just in using them but in the philosophy of how you should go about the process of using them. To carry on from what Senator Bartlett is saying, and to endorse what Senator Harradine said, why use arguments that have nothing to do with the issue or the legislation and which are based purely on emotion and are even approaching an appeal to prejudice?

talk.start.para: —I think Senator Cooney and I are slightly at cross-purposes. Senator Bartlett and I were discussing the tabling speech that I put down. He was hanging on the word `might'. If I imply that he should not be looking at the speech in that detail, I apologise. I was saying that that is taking a word like that out of context when we are looking at a generic group of refugees, some of whom might have a claim on another country and some of whom might not. Using the word `might' does not mean that everyone might have a claim in that country. This tabling speech, although used as an explanatory memorandum in interpreting the law, has to be seen in context. The context of that paragraph is that we were talking about a generic group of people, some of whom might have claims to other countries and some of whom might not. That is why the word `might' was used.

speech.para: I do not know that I can go into everything Senator Cooney talked about. In talking about the training of officers on the use of firearms, the briefing note refers to their training on not only the use of firearms but also on the safe storage of firearms and in using negotiation. It says that the training is of six to seven weeks duration. The main emphasis is on conflict resolution and incident de-escalation so that potentially dangerous situations can be resolved without the need to resort to any level of force.

We ought to leave the AFP, which is more expert at this than us, to train the customs officers in the way that AFP officers are trained. It is not just about how to put bullets in a gun and shoot. The emphasis is on conflict resolution and incident de-escalation. I have been working as a principal patron for the safe havens. I have been very impressed with the officers working in those safe havens. There has been an obvious cultural change in the defence forces in dealing with conflict resolution and incident de-escalation. They have used their skills enormously well. We have also seen that with the troops in East Timor. That is the sort of culture that exists. It is the sort of culture that is engendered in the AFP and which will be passed on to the customs officers who are being trained.

talk.start.para: —I would like to press the issue a bit further. Noting the comments of the parliamentary secretary about the value of a briefing from ministers' staff or departmental staff, I certainly have always found it valuable to get information from those sources, whether through briefings or committee hearings. But I think it is also important to get on the record in the parliament the operation of these measures. Again I emphasise that the princi ple that the minister has stated these measures are able to address in the amendment is one that the Democrats support, but the question is how it will operate in practice.

speech.para: Senator McKiernan said to look at other sections of the amendment. I am trying to look at this as a package and not just pull one line out of context. But, in relation to those sections, the minister may, after considering advice from UNHCR, declare various countries, and he may determine that section does not apply to a non-citizen—non-compellable, non-reviewable, non-appealable. It is difficult to see how that is a sufficient guarantee that Australia as a nation will act in a way that meets its obligations. Senator Patterson said that parliament acts all the time to give various powers to ministers to do various things. That is fine but here we are giving power to a minister that he is not obliged to use, and no-one can do anything about it if he does not. That gives me some concern.

Linked to that I would like to get further clarification of the operation of this amendment. As I understand it, linking to section 91N(3), the minister can declare that specified countries provide access or protection to people who meet relevant human rights standards or he can revoke such a declaration. Is that meant to indicate that only those countries that have been declared by the minister as specified countries that meet those standards will come into play in the overall operation of this amendment?

talk.start.para: —I have been advised, Senator Bartlett, that if a person comes from a third country the bar does not operate unless the minister has made a declaration that the country is safe. That is the only answer I can give you. We could sit here all day debating whether or not the minister will use his power appropriately or not. I am sure that if it were not appropriately used you, if you were here, Senator McKiernan, if he were here, or whoever else were here, would ensure that the minister addresses that issue. I do not know what else you can do. You want it to be a compellable power. I suppose that is what you are asking for.

—I am trying to get on the record exactly how these provisions will operate to ensure that we do not leave ourselves open to the risk of being party to refoulement. I will move away from the issue of ministerial discretion—I think that point has been made as much as it needs to be made and will not be progressed further.

speech.para: Another question, though, that I would like to ask goes to the foreshadowed first amendment that I have circulated: the issue of the non-citizen having a well-founded fear that a country will return them to a place where they will be persecuted. In that circumstance the bar does not operate. I foreshadowed an amendment to insert `directly or indirectly' in the provision so that it is clear that that well-founded fear does not relate just to the third country shunting them straight back to Iraq or wherever it is but also to moving them out of their borders and leaving them to the vagaries of fate, in which case they may end up eventually being shuttled back. There are cases of people who get shuffled from one country to the next. They are deemed to be illegal in one place, they are sent back to the last port of call and then they are bounced all the way back down the chain. That happens now.

I would like, firstly, to get clarification of that potential problem. As I read the amendment, it seems to mean that the return would have to be direct from the third country back to the problem country—Iraq or wherever—rather than just sending them away so that they become someone else's problem, which means that they lose those chains of protection.

talk.start.para: —In relation to the first point, if you look at amendment 91N(5), it says:

speech.para: The Minister must cause a copy of a declaration, or of a revocation of a declaration, to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 2 sitting days of that House after the Minister makes the declaration or revokes the declaration.

I think the other point you are making about direct or indirect return goes to the heart of your amendment and the amendment in which you are proposing to add to the existing wording in the government's amendment. It is clearly Australia's intention to fully meet its convention obligations not to refoule refugees. I made that point specifically and clearly in the speech I made before I tabled the amendments. I did that on purpose to reiterate that that was the government's obligation and commitment. The amendment that the Democrats are proposing would add words that create uncertainty in the meaning. What constitutes `indirectly' would create a field day for litigants seeking to undermine the legislation. It would be a complicating and retrograde step which would make the reading of the government's amendment unclear. The government wording fully meets Australia's convention obligations. We have made the commitment that people will not be refouled.

talk.start.para: —I appreciate the parliamentary secretary's continual reiteration that it is Australia's intention to meet our obligations. What I am concerned about is that we do not enact legislation that provides inadequate safeguards or loopholes where those obligations are met. Good intentions are always wonderful but, if you are just saying that it is the government's intention to uphold our obligations, you are basically asking everybody to just trust us and saying, `This is our intention. We're going to uphold our obligations.' If that is all we are going to have, we may as well scrap the legislative provisions for a refugee review tribunal and all that and say, `Look, it's our intention. We're going to uphold our obligations. That is what we're going to do, and we don't need all these complicating legislative requirements to guarantee that not just the government meet our obligations but future governments meet our obligations.' I do not think we can rely on good intentions. To progress things, I will formally move the Democrat amendment to the government amendment. Then I am sure Senator McKiernan can stand up and tell me what is wrong with it. I move:

speech.para: Item 65, paragraph 36(5)(a), after "will", insert ", directly or indirectly,".

talk.start.para: —Never miss an opportunity when you are given the call. The opposition do not support the Democrat amendment. We are satisfied from the series of negotiations that have been undertaken, which I have referred to before, and also from a more detailed examination of the government amendment as it appeared before us that the provisions contained here in the amendment will alleviate the concerns expressed by Senator Bartlett. We have those concerns, but we are satisfied that the words here overcome those concerns. I keep reading it, and I cannot see why the addition of the words `directly' and `indirectly' after `return the non-citizen to another country' will help in any way. Were they to do so, we would most seriously look to supporting them, but unfortunately we cannot see our way through, and we cannot see that your suggested amendment is adding any safeguards that are not there already to the government's amendment. For those reasons, we will not be supporting them.

—I want to explain a bit further for the record the reason behind the Democrats first amendment: it is to ensure that there is that extra protection. My understanding of the principle of non-refoulement is that a country has an obligation to ensure not just that someone does not get returned directly to a place where they face persecution but that that country is not a party to that person ending up back there. The fact that they go through two or three other countries in the process does not remove Australia's obligation to not be a party to them ending up back in a place where they face persecution.

speech.para: The government may well say that that is the intention of the way this amendment is going to operate. It will ensure that people are not returned indirectly via third, fourth, fifth, sixth and seventh countries to a place where they face persecution. This is simply intended to put that beyond doubt. However, it appears that the Senate is not of a similar view, so I will not specifically elaborate further on that point.

talk.start.para: —I am supporting this amendment. I do not see for the life of me why the government or the opposition does not. It recognises that countries do place considerable pressure on returning refugees to go back to their previous country. This pressure could take the shape of a whole range of different measures. I really have not heard anything stated by Senator Patterson or Senator McKiernan to suggest otherwise. Here we have the words:

speech.para: (5) Also, if the non-citizen has a well-founded fear that:
(a) a country will return the non-citizen to another country . . .

All Senator Bartlett is proposing is that after the `will' there should be `directly or indirectly'. What we are interested in, of course, is safety. What we are interested in as a country is our obligations not to refoule. If this refoulement takes place directly, we are presumably covered by the wording here. If it occurs indirectly, are we covered? That is the simple question that I am asking the minister.

In the event of there being an indication or a valid suspicion that the country will indirectly return the non-citizen to another country, what then? Is the minister saying on behalf of the government that, if there is a well-founded fear that the country to which we are returning the asylum seeker will ultimately and indirectly influence that person's transfer to another country, this wording—without Senator Bartlett's amendment—covers that situation? That is all I am asking. I do not think I have heard an explanation from the parliamentary secretary on that. Have I made it clear? Does this mean that, if the non-citizen has a well-founded fear—and a well-founded fear can be tested—that a country will indirectly return that non-citizen to another country, that is covered? Is that what the wording means?

talk.start.para: —I do not know that I am going to be able to convince Senator Bartlett or Senator Harradine. At the minister's request, prior to tabling the speech regarding the amendments, I specifically and very clearly stated that the government would not refoule refugees. One of the problems that arises out of the use of the words `directly or indirectly' is that it can create mischievous litigation. The legislation has to be considered in conjunction with administrative arrangements. There are clear intervention powers and there are public guidelines being prepared, and the convention does not say how countries deliver on their obligations.

speech.para: The key to the debate is that we have indicated that we will do that. One can never speak for future governments, but it has been a tradition of Australian governments of both persuasions to deliver on those obligations. To put those words in makes it difficult in terms of whether there is a time limit: there are all sorts of interpretations that can be put on it. The government's preferred position is not to have the words `directly or indirectly' in that clause.

talk.start.para: —I do not know what words can be used in this debate that would put to rest the concerns that Senator Harradine has raised. I have been pondering in my mind previous circumstances where persons who came into Australia and claimed refugee status failed in their claim, but where the government, together with the embassies of other nations, was able to make arrangements for the individual not to return to their country but to go to a different country. For example, I can recall that, with the Vietnamese boat people, a number of people who failed to get protection here in Australia actually ended up getting a visa to go to the United States. You could end up with the scenario where that individual, while they had failed to get protection in Australia, had, after they had removed themselves to the United States, come across some difficulties which caused the United States to remove them out of the United States.

speech.para: I cannot see where Australia's obligations under the refoulement provisions of the refugee convention and protocols would be brought into play in this scenario, for two reasons. Firstly, we are dealing with the laws of the United States—and I say that in the hypothetical sense, because we have had experience in that, as I indicated. Secondly, because the individual had failed in a protection visa application within Australia, I would have thought that would have relieved Australia of its obligations, certainly under the refugee convention and the subsequent protocols.
Amendment (Senator Bartlett's) not agreed to.
