debateinfo.title: NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY LEVIES REGULATIONS (VALIDATION AND COMMENCEMENT OF AMENDMENTS) BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: —I do not think I have time to put my intended comments on the record. In view of the time difficulties I will just indicate on behalf of the opposition that we do not object to the passage of the National Residue Survey Levies Regulations (Validation and Commencement of Amendments) Bill 1999 . I do, however, draw attention to the remarks which the shadow minister, Mr O'Connor, made in the other place yesterday on behalf of the opposition. I endorse those remarks and indicate that we do not oppose the passage of this bill.

—I thank Senator Forshaw for his comments. I wish simply to indicate that the government puts forward the National Residue Survey Levies Regulations (Validation and Commencement of Amendments) Bill 1999 to correct an inconsistency between the starting dates of the Primary Industries Levies and Charges (National Residue Survey Levies) Regulations 1998 and amendments made to those regulations. I seek leave to incorporate my summing-up in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.

This Bill corrects an inconsistency between the starting dates of the Primary Industries Levies and Charges (National Residue Survey Levies) Regulations 1998 (the National Residue Survey Levy Regulations) and amendments made to these regulations by Statutory Rules 1998 No. 182.

The purpose of Statutory Rules 182 was to make a last minute amendment to the rate of the National Residue Survey sheep and lamb transactions levy. The request for this change came from industry. The new `per head' levy rate was to have commenced on the 1st of August 1998, at the same time as the National Residue Survey Levy Regulations.

However, following a request for clarification from the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, the Chief General Counsel delivered a legal opinion on 6 May this year that Statutory Rules 182 had been validly made, but had failed to commence at the same time as the Regulations.

This opinion meant the `per head' National Residue Survey levy rate for sheep and lamb transactions first struck in April 1998 has technically been the operative levy rate until now, not the rate proposed by Statutory Rules 182.
The sheep and lamb industry has recently reconfirmed its commitment to the levy rates provided for in Statutory Rules 182.

The impact on levy payers of this technical anomaly will be nil once this Bill has been passed, as the levy has been collected since the 1st of August 1998 last year at the rate requested by industry.

This rate was established to meet industry's commitment to its National Residue Survey residue-monitoring program. There has been no adverse impact on the operation of this very important program, a program that underwrites the residue-free status of Australia's sheep and lamb meat products, as a result of the technical error that passage of this Bill will correct.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services. Can the minister inform the Senate why staff of her department are contacting disability employ ment service providers in Victoria, Queensland and New South Wales, informing them that `employer payments have now ceased for any further new applicants to Supported Wage'? Is the minister aware that this scheme saw 3,188 people with disabilities in 1998-99 reduce their reliance on the disability support pension and enter into employment? How can the minister justify shutting down this obviously successful incentive while, at the same time, maintaining `many people with a capacity to work needlessly stay on disability payments for a long time'?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I have no idea about that at all, and I will chase it up as soon as I can. Senator West, I hope I might get an answer for you before the end of question time.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I have copies of three letters that the department has sent to organisations in the three states. Can the minister confirm that, according to departmental correspondence from New South Wales, the supported wage system approved over 1,200 new applications in 1998-99, putting it 20 per cent over the annual target? Is the minister aware that the manager of the department's New South Wales Economic and Social Participation branch dubbed this increase `unsustainable'? Can the minister inform the Senate why a scheme that offers an annual average subsidy of just $1,600 to each worker, thousands of dollars less than what the Commonwealth would be paying out in disability support pensions, is unsustainable?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —No. I will get that information as part of the information Senator West has already asked me for.

—My question is directed to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Will the Assistant Treasurer inform the Senate of the details of the Mid-year economic and fiscal outlook released today? What are the prospects for continued strong economic growth, increasing job opportunities and greater prosperity for Australian families?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Senator Watson, for that important question. I am very happy to inform the Senate about the release today of the Mid-year economic and fiscal outlook . The forecast for economic growth in 1999-2000 has been revised upward from three per cent to 3.5 per cent. Growth the following year is expected to be higher, at 3.75 per cent. This is an excellent outlook for the Australian economy, particularly given the Asian crisis over the last two years. The underlying cash surplus is expected to be $3.4 billion in 1999-2000, and surpluses are expected to continue through the forecast period.

answer.para: Perhaps the most significant news from today's press release is that employment growth is expected to be stronger than forecast at budget time. The budget forecast unemployment of 7.5 per cent by June 2000. This has now been revised downwards to 6.75 per cent. The predicted reduction in the unemployment rate builds on the almost 600,000 more jobs that now exist than existed when this government came to office in March 1996. The good news is that employment growth is expected to remain at two per cent in 2000-01, raising the prospect of further declines in unemployment.

Growing job opportunities and increasing prosperity for Australian families did not happen by luck. They happened through sound management of the economy and good governance, which have been the hallmarks of the Howard government. We have put into place the economic fundamentals to weather the Asian financial storm and to continue to grow our economy while others in our region have floundered. It is also important to remember how the transparency of fiscal policy has been improved through our charter of budget honesty.

Under this government, the government Mid-year economic and fiscal outlook is a detailed report providing a clear statement of the current budgetary and economic position of the nation. Compare that with our predecessors, the Keating government. In their final year, they produced as their mid-year review this document—a two-page summary of forecast and then a tax press release. Compare this with what the Treasurer has released today. This is what being fiscally responsible and transparent is all about. This government does have sufficient achievements in the economy to fill a book this size whereas, as we remember all too painfully, Labor's achievements were very few and far between. That is the contrast. The mid-year review today confirms that the government is running an economy with increasing employment, low inflation, low interest rates, high growth and a surplus budget, with a new and modern, fairer tax system to come.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Newman, Minister for Family and Community Services. It also concerns the supported wage system for people with disabilities and the minister's department's decision to cut back the program's growth. Can the minister inform the Senate why her department considers it to be fair and equitable to limit the wage subsidy to just 45 per cent of those workers with disabilities who require job placement in 1999-2000? Just what are the other 55 per cent of disabled people supposed to do without that important wage support? Given her seminal speech on welfare reform, does she consider this to be good enough?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I have already told Senator West that I will get her an answer to her questions. Senator Evans's question directly relates to these, except that he chooses to be political about people with disabilities. I have made it very clear that I do not believe the existing system—
—You said that you wanted them off DSP.

—Clearly, Senator Evans does not want to hear the answer. I made it very clear in my National Press Club speech, and I have made it clear in other fora, that over the years people with disabilities have not been as well served by Australia as they might have been. Certainly, if we are going to do better by people with disabilities to help them become more self-reliant and have an opportunity to be in the work force, the government has to provide better assistance and provide it earlier. I have not cut their assistance, but I will get you a detailed answer on the specifics of your question.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. Will the minister inform the Senate how the government's changes to business taxation will help create jobs and provide tax relief to small investors?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —There is no doubt that one of the key aims of the overhaul of business taxation has been to help Australian businesses create more jobs. This government already has a strong record on job creation, with more than 570,000 new jobs created since we were first elected. Last month alone, an additional 47,000 jobs were created and the unemployment rate fell from 7.4 per cent to 7.1 per cent. The low interest rate and low inflation environment we have created has helped Australian businesses to grow and employ more people. As we have already heard from the Assistant Treasurer earlier in question time, the Mid-year economic and fiscal outlook has revised growth for the Australian economy up from three per cent to 3.5 per cent this year, with growth expected to be 3.75 per cent the following year.

answer.para: But we acknowledge that more always needs to be done. That is why we pushed through our reforms to the income tax system earlier this year, and that new tax system will benefit businesses and our farmers in many ways, including by reducing the cost of transport and ensuring that all exports are GST free. The next logical step is to reform our business tax system. Under our changes, the company tax rate will fall to 30 per cent in two stages. This will be among the lowest company tax rates in our region, making Australia an attractive place for overseas investors to do business. At the same time, the package will reduce the compliance burden for 95 per cent of businesses and about 99 per cent of our primary producers. Businesses and farmers will spend less time and money on doing their books and more time and money on creating wealth and providing jobs.

The changes to the capital gains tax system, which have now been agreed to by the Labor Party, are also important for business and small investors and make our capital gains tax system internationally competitive. Under the changes, individuals will pay tax on only 50 per cent of the capital gain. This will encourage investment and savings and should also see more Australians investing in Australia's equity markets. It is worth remembering that, under this government, Australia has arguably become the greatest share owning democracy in the world. For example, the recent Telstra 2 share offer attracted more than 400,000 new investors. And these are not high rollers—77 per cent of individuals paying capital gains tax have taxable incomes under $50,000. In addition to this, all Australians with superannuation will benefit from the reduction in the capital gains tax burden on superannuation funds.

Once these changes are implemented, we will see more business confidence, more investment, more savings, more growth and, most importantly, more jobs. I congratulate the Labor Party on finally coming up with a policy—even if that policy was to support the government's tax policy. I would suggest to them that, when they look at our alternatives in social security, Aboriginal affairs, environment and regional development, they will see further alternatives to devising their own policies, which has obviously been too difficult. They can do what they did yesterday in these areas as well and support our policies, and the nation will be better off.

talk.start.para: —My question is also to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the minister to his recent announcement of funding to voluntary conservation organisations. Can the minister confirm that the average grant has decreased by some 30 per cent over the last five years? Isn't it a fact that the minister has politicised the funding process by, first, increasing funding—in some cases by over 50 per cent over the last two years—to those organisations that have supported the government and, second, by decreasing funding to those organisations that have criticised government, in some cases by over 70 per cent during the same period? Doesn't such decision making represent the triumph of spite and vindictiveness over democratic decision making?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I congratulate Senator Bolkus. He is now averaging one environment question every 50 days, which is certainly an improvement on the beginning of this week when it was one environment question every 150 days. I would only suggest to him that, if he now starts doing a bit of hard work in the area, he might be able to come up with some difficult questions as well.
—Senator Hill, I draw your attention to the question.
—If he researched this matter seriously, he would find that basically funding has been maintained by this government at the rates—
—That is a lie.
—Withdraw that, Senator Bolkus.
—I withdraw. It is an untruth.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —Basically, funding has been maintained at the same rates as those of the previous government. I will check it, but I think you will find that that is right. We will put down the specific figures and we will see who is misleading the Senate. Basically, funding has been maintained; basically, the same guidelines that Senator Faulkner had have been maintained. The major difference is that we are giving money to more environment groups, and we are spreading it more fairly across Australia. The major distinction is that we are not just backing the favourites, which of course was what Senator Faulkner did. We are giving a fair distribution to groups across Australia that can contribute in both advocacy and performance on the ground. By and large, those groups are making a very worthwhile contribution to better environmental outcomes and certainly a much better contribution than that being made by Senator Bolkus.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Maybe the minister ought to spend a bit more time researching answers than trying to make cheap points that do not work. Isn't it also the case that the Howard government has reneged on public commitments it made regarding the Olympics and today has withdrawn funding for Green Games Watch 2000, the independent environment watchdog of the Olympic Games? Has the minister actually forgotten John Howard's 1996 commitment to uphold every funding commitment made by Labor to the 2000 Games? Where is the common sense in withdrawing the Commonwealth's 50 per cent funding for this watchdog 10 months before the games are being held? Given that the cutting of funding leaves New South Wales to fund 100 per cent of independent environmental audits of the 2000 Games, isn't this just another example of this Prime Minister's spiteful payback to New South Wales for being forced off the official opening ceremony?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —Unfortunately, once again the question is asked without having done the basic research. When Senator Bolkus researches the issue, he will find that this organisation was funded in an overseeing role in relation to the construction of facilities. Those facilities are now constructed. They came back and said they wanted to be funded in a new and continuing role of overseeing other matters including the carrying out of the games themselves. That was never the original purpose. They received very substantial public funding from both the Commonwealth government and the New South Wales government to do the job they were entrusted to do, and that has now been completed.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. Is the minister aware of the US proposal for a working group on trade and labour to consider issues such as the `examination of the extent of forced or exploitative child labour in industries engaged in international trade' at the WTO? Is the minister also aware of the British government move to put discussion of child labour and the enforcement of ILO convention 182 on the WTO meeting agenda, or is this government still determined to avoid a discussion of general labour standards at the WTO meeting in order to avoid alienating other members of the WTO? Will the minister give us a commitment to raise these issues at the WTO?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —In answer to this question without notice—a bit of notice might have helped to give a better answer—
—What's that brief you've got in front of you?
—How come you've got a written answer?
—A new standing order, is it? Is this what you are coming to expect?

—In this instance, actually, Senator Stott Despoja put down a notice of motion. That was the source of some of the guidance that I have received.This issue arises out of the establishment of a WTO working group to carry out analytical work on trade and labour standards. Whilst the US is proposing that labour standards, generally, be placed on the agenda of the WTO, the government understands that the US is not seeking any specific reference to exploitative child labour. Furthermore, the government was not aware that the United Kingdom may be supporting the US proposal. Putting child labour on the WTO agenda would lead to unnecessary and inefficient duplication, with more than one international body examining the specific problem of child labour. The government believes that the ILO should continue to have prime responsibility for international labour matters. The ILO is already doing significant work relating to child labour by providing technical assistance to those countries with a demonstrated problem. The ILO has also established minimum international labour standards dealing with the subject. Most recently, in June 1999, the ILO Conference adopted a new convention on the worst forms of child labour. Australia strongly supported the adoption of this new standard and, furthermore, played a significant role in the development of the convention, helping member states reach an agreed position.

answer.para: The Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business has commenced the process of consulting with other relevant government agencies, including the state and territory governments as well as relevant representative employer and worker organisations—the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Australian Council of Trade Unions—addressing compliance with the provisions of ILO convention 182. This process is a prerequisite for considering ratification of the convention. Australia already complies with the principles of the abolition of child labour as espoused in the ILO Declaration on Fundamental Principles and Rights at Work adopted by the ILO in 1998. Relevant federal, state and territory legislation dealing with compulsory education, child welfare, occupational safety and health and an industry specific minimum age for employment ensures compliance with the principles.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer but, given that ILO convention 182 is the only ILO convention ever to have been adopted unanimously by the 174 countries—including Australia—doesn't the minister agree that the prohibition of exploitative child labour is a rare issue of international concurrence which the Australian government should and could raise at the WTO forum next week? I clarify for the minister that this government is deliberately avoiding the issue at the WTO forum. Given that the minister has just boasted about the role Australia has played in relation to the signing of that convention and the announcement in June this year, will the government ratify that convention to give it international effect, and will it incorporate it into Australian law to give it domestic effect?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I agree with the honourable senator that this is a vitally important matter, and that is why Australia has been so active. We obviously have our own domestic response, which renders illegal such behaviour. But we also look to encourage and support other countries in adopting similar standards and, particularly in this instance, we are doing it through the appropriate international body, which is the ILO. So in terms of using such opportunities as present to further advance that case, I think the honourable senator will get a sympathetic hearing from this government. But in terms of trying to convert the WTO into an ILO, we say that that is a fundamental mistake. There is a mechanism internationally to pursue that matter and that is the correct way and the most effective way in which to do it.

—My question is directed to Senator Vanstone, the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Does the minister believe that High Court Chief Justice Murray Gleeson is correct when he said that the Howard Government's cutbacks to legal aid are causing problems of `substantial practical dimensions' which are threatening the efficiency of Australian courts and their ability to deliver justice?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator McKiernan for his question. Even though I think we have very different views on this, I understand that we both have a longstanding interest in this issue. The brief that I have does not refer to any comments made by the Chief Justice, but it is on the point of legal aid funding. It is not a long answer and I am not trying to distract from the issue. I will ask the Attorney if he has anything to say about the comments you have referred to, but let me give you the following information. In response to calls from the Law Council for an additional $126 million over three years for legal aid, we think it is far too early to be talking about the final level of Commonwealth funding to each state and territory. We will be renegotiating the legal aid agreements that will take effect in July next year. While we cannot talk about the funding levels at this point, it is fair to note that there has not been any suggestion that the Commonwealth's national contribution to legal aid will be cut. In fact, while the final level of funding has not yet been determined, the Commonwealth has already indicated in forward budget estimates that the overall amount of Commonwealth legal aid funding will be maintained, and the Attorney is now in the process of negotiating new legal aid agreements with the states and territories. Future funding levels for individual jurisdictions will be determined through that process.

answer.para: Senator McKiernan, as you well understand, the cut to legal aid funding made by this government some time ago was in fact a call to the states to pay their fair share. The Commonwealth is paying for legal aid in relation to Commonwealth matters and has said to the states that it is their responsibility to pay for legal aid for state matters.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for part of the answer that she gave me. By way of background prior to asking the supplementary question, in Chief Justice Gleeson's statement he indicated that 28 per cent of the litigants were unrepresented at hearings before single judges of the High Court of Australia. Can the minister indicate whether all of those unrepresented litigants were dealing in matters of state law or Commonwealth law and why they were unrepresented? Will the minister concede that cutbacks to legal aid are compromising the delivery of justice and are creating an unnecessary expense to the community through inefficiency, waste and overburdening of the court lists?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —Senator McKiernan, I will endeavour to get some information—if I cannot, we will get it at estimates next week—in relation to those people who appear before the High Court unrepresented, whether they do so by choice, whether they are state or federal matters or what. So we will get some answers in relation to that. Do I concede that the commitment to ensure that the states pay their fair share is leading to inefficiencies? Quite the opposite, Senator McKiernan. With some pressure on the purse strings I think you can make the case that it is in fact forcing the administration of legal aid in the states to look for more efficiencies and to find them for the benefit of people who need to use legal aid.

—My question is addressed to Senator Alston, Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. Does the minister recall commit ments that he gave on 19 March this year as a result of the Blue Sky High Court decision that the government will ensure that foreign access to Australian television local content quotas will be explicitly confined to New Zealand, thus confirming there will be no flow-on to other international treaties, and that the government will ensure that Australia's cultural objectives to the audiovisual sector are taken into account in negotiating all future trade agreements? If so, will the government back up the minister's promises and ensure that in the upcoming round of World Trade Organisation negotiations cultural industries are explicitly excluded from any further trade liberalisation?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Yes, I do recall the general thrust of what Senator Bourne refers to on 19 March. Certainly it was our concern at the time to ensure that there was no slippage in relation to that essentially one-off arrangement with New Zealand. I am not familiar with the precise detail of what case the Australian government might be arguing at the WTO in Seattle, but I think it is fair to say that there is an awareness that, whilst countries like France and Canada are pushing very hard for increased protection for their own cultural diversity programs, we are disinclined to support them or to move in the opposite direction. My understanding is that we will simply be supporting the status quo. We have no intentions of going beyond our commitments, but I will check with the Minister for Trade and see whether I can get a more detailed answer for Senator Bourne.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer. Can he tell me if I am correct in assuming then that we do not intend to explicitly protect our cultural industries in any future trade liberalisation and that the government just intends to let things float as they are without that protection?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I am not sure what Senator Bourne means by our taking action to protect our own industries. We can state our position; we can adhere to it when the multilateral negotiations are taking place; we can ensure that we always put our own interests first and that we do not deviate from that in the course of those negotiations. I have no reason to think that we are proposing to move away from the publicly announced position and the arrangements to which you refer. But I will see if I can get some more explicit commitments on that front.

—My question without notice is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Can the minister confirm that the ad hoc committee, established by the Commonwealth and the states and chaired by the departmental officer Mr Gallagher to look into the credentials of Greenwich University, has concluded that Greenwich is not a bona fide Australian university? Can the minister further confirm that the committee has found against Greenwich on a range of grounds and criteria? Will the minister now detail those grounds?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —I am not aware of where that ad hoc committee is at the moment. But can I say that this has been a thorough inquiry by an ad hoc committee which the Commonwealth recognised needed to be established and one which Senator Carr tried to beat up into something which it was not. But I will make inquiries to see where that committee is at.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it that the minister is taking that question on notice. I would ask him further: does the minister agree that there are already several unaccredited universities like Greenwich operating on the Internet and passing themselves off as bona fide Australian higher education institutions by various means? Does the minister further agree that the government at the moment has no regulations or legislation in place to stop a flood of these dubious providers from passing themselves off as properly established Australian universities? When will the government act to protect this highly important export industry by moving to require accreditation of private higher education providers?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —Senator Carr well knows the great reputation that Australia enjoys internationally in relation to its higher education sector, and that is evidenced by people who want to come to this country and study here. I think it is unfortunate that Senator Carr beats up on the higher education sector in this way. This government is ensuring that the higher education sector delivers both to domestic students and to those students who come here. It is time that Senator Carr looked to the advantages and the positives rather than trying to create something which does not exist.

—My question is to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone. Will the minister inform the Senate of the latest crime statistics from the Australian Institute of Criminology, and what do these statistics reveal about the causes of crime?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Mason for his question. Yesterday the Australian Institute of Criminology did release its Facts and Figures 1999 booklet on Australian crime. Crime statistics are never entirely good news. But, unfortunately, yesterday the shadow minister for justice and customs could not help himself and threw himself further in the gutter than he has ever done before. He said in a press release that the crime figures show:

answer.para: . . . a growing anti-social response by people who feel that they have been left out, left behind and are not a part of Australia's economic success.

So let us be clear and make no mistake about what Mr Kerr was saying. He was saying that under this government there is a widening gap between rich and poor and he was going further by saying that the poor are turning to crime.

It is a shameful exercise for the Labor Party to ever let one of its shadow ministers blame the poor for rising crime trends. It is a disgrace! This press release is a disgrace to the nation. It is a shameful thing for the Labor Party to be putting out a release saying, `Oh, well, it is more poor. Let's blame the poor.' You people should be sacking him. You should be marching off to Beazley's office, knocking on the door and saying, `Get rid of this bloke.' It is an outrageous claim to be making. But let me let the genie out of the bottle.
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The level of noise has become unacceptably high.

—The GINI coefficient is the accepted measure of income inequality. Between 1982 and 1988, under Labor, the GINI coefficient, which measures the gap between rich and poor, grew dramatically. So the gap between rich and poor grew dramatically when you people were in government. However, between 1996 and 1997, under this government, the coefficient has increased by what? A half a per cent. So, yes, these people created the gap between rich and poor, and we have not been able to close it. But we certainly have not dramatically increased it, as they did.

answer.para: What is true is that Australia is moving forward as a whole. The ABS income survey shows that the degree of inequality in income distribution remained almost unchanged between 1994-95 and 1997-98. So it is the Bureau of Statistics which says that the degree of inequality in income distribution has remained, relatively speaking, unchanged. So there is the story: those people created the gap; we have not closed it, but we certainly have not widened it. Under this government the economic growth rate is leading the developed world.
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I will have to go to a supplementary if I cannot get this out.
—Order! Labor senators will stop shouting. It is making it difficult to hear, certainly for those who are listening.

—I can understand Labor wanting to shout about this. They would not want everybody to know that the gap between rich and poor was created under their government and that their shadow minister is blaming the poor for any increase in crime. I would be embarrassed about it too. I would try to shout it down. I would not want everybody to know that. Let us turn to the question of poverty and crime. Duncan Kerr wants to say that it is the poor people. Perhaps he has not recognised the dollar value of Alan Bond's one fraud—(Time expired)
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the minister expand on the relationship between crime and poverty?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —You do not know how much I would like to expand on it. Just consider this: the dollar value of Alan Bond's one fraud is equal to all the household burglaries committed in Australia for 84 weeks. One big white-collar crime can add up to all the burglaries in Australia over 84 weeks. If Mr Kerr wants to do something about crime, he should stop blaming all the poor people in Australia and start focusing a bit on some white-collar crime. He should start getting it properly in perspective. He should start mentioning that drugs play a part in it. Why didn't he tell us that homicide has decreased over the last year? Why didn't he tell us some good news, such as that sexual assault and motor vehicle theft are not on the increase? Why didn't he tell us that armed robbery with firearms decreased by 12.6 per cent and that most of the increase in armed robberies was where? In New South Wales. Why does this man come out when the only thing he can do is blame the poor? It is a disgrace, and you should get rid of him.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation. Is the minister aware of the Prime Minister's speech to Nelson Mandela in South Africa on 15 November? Is it not the case that the Prime Minister in his speech celebrated the moral leadership, moral depth, compassion and capacity for forgiveness and reconciliation that Mandela has given to the world as an example? Will the Prime Minister now exercise the same qualities he recognises in the former President of South Africa and sincerely apologise on behalf of the Australian government to the stolen generation in an act of true moral leadership, moral depth, compassion and reconciliation? Is this not exactly what Nelson Mandela was suggesting to the Prime Minister, or is John Howard too stubborn to act on Mandela's example to lead an effective reconciliation process?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Crossin for the question. Senator Crossin would also recognise that Nelson Mandela described Mr Howard as a great man. Nelson Mandela recognised him.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are far too many people shouting and interrupting.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The Prime Minister awarded Nelson Mandela a Companion of Australia. There is no question that all of us hold Nelson Mandela in very high regard as a leader in the world.
—Senator Forshaw and Senator George Campbell, I have just called the Senate to order.

—I refute the suggestion that the Prime Minister has not shown leadership in this regard. It was the Prime Minister who moved a joint—from both sides—motion of reconciliation on 26 August. It was carried in both houses. We now have Senator Crossin trying to politicise reconciliation. If there is one thing I am against, it is politicising reconciliation. As I have said on previous occasions, once you get into this category of starting point scoring about reconciliation, you drag us all down. Reconciliation is in the hearts and minds of all of us. We either have it or we haven't. If we have not got it, we start politicising it. We start trying to point score. We start trying to drag it down into the gutter. We get to gutter politics. That is what Senator Crossin is doing with this. She has to recognise that reconciliation is something that should be done by each and every one of us. Once she starts politicising, as she is trying to do today, she denigrates it. She does us all harm. I am not going to reply in a politicised manner in relation to this question.

question.para: The Prime Minister has taken a leadership role and we as a government have taken a leadership role with regard to the Council of Reconciliation. The Council of Reconciliation has produced a draft document which is going out to all Australians to reply to. They will report back in May next year as a result of their consultations. I expect that that will be acted on in a spirit of reconciliation by all members of parliament.

talk.start.para: —Where were you all? You are a bunch of hypocrites.
—Senator George Campbell, withdraw that.
—I withdraw.
—I invite senators to read and think about the standing orders and to think about their behaviour.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Besides the fact that great men are often good leaders and lead effectively, does the minister agree that the Prime Minister was absolutely wrong in his long history of personally criticising the use of economic and sporting sanctions against the former apartheid regime in South Africa? That is another trait he blindly shared with Margaret Thatcher. Why can't Australia's own backward looking man consider his own past and admit that he was wrong if he is such a great leader? Why could he not say sorry to Nelson Mandela for his own part in opposing sanctions against the apartheid regime?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —John Howard will be shown to be one of the greatest Prime Ministers of this country. When you consider the present Prime Minister against the likes of Bob Hawke and Paul Keating, the man who nearly destroyed the country in two years—your previous leader, who now appears to be a Labor icon—John Howard will be regarded by history as the greatest leader of this country since Sir Robert Menzies.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. The government's deregulation of the telecommunications market is delivering better services and reduced costs to Australian consumers. Will the minister inform the Senate of the developments in the telecommunications pricing arrangements and the benefits that these are delivering? Is the minister aware of any alternative policy approaches? If so, what would be the impact if these were implemented?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —It is a very good news story. But you don't need to take my word for it. Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu released a review this week which said it all. It said that deregulation of the telecommunications industry was having a marked effect on Australia's leading corporations, that many of them had taken advantage of increased competition, that 69 per cent of the companies surveyed had realised savings of at least 10 per cent and that the magnitude of the savings seemed to be getting even bigger. If 69 per cent doesn't impress you, it certainly impresses me. You can keep running that furphy as long as you like, Senator Bishop, but it won't wash. It hasn't washed in the past and it won't wash in the future. The important thing is that this has all come about because of the deregulation we embarked upon, which resulted in full and open competition, on 1 July 1997. Ever since that time we have had absolute competition on world's best practice standards. In Australia now we have without doubt the most competitive and dynamic telecommunications regime in the world. The pace of change is obviously making some people on the other side of the chamber feel a bit dizzy. The most they can do is ignore it, rather than embrace it as something that is contributing to increased levels of productivity, generating a lot more jobs around Australia and making Australia much more internationally competitive.

answer.para: One of the most significant advances in recent times has been the fact that we now have two carriers offering rates of 15c for local calls and two offering 17c and 17.5c. Who are they? RSL, AAPT, OneTel and Primus. Telstra no doubt will have to follow them down as well. The significance of that is that we now have very vigorous competition in the last area, where previously there had been some fairly cosy arrangements. Now it is all happening at the local loop level. That is because there have been declared services, and players are taking advantage of it.

This removes the last fig leaf for Labor. Mr Stephen Smith's attitude to privatisation is, `We cannot embark on that just now because we want to ensure that we have a fully competitive telecommunications market.' Now we have. So in principle Labor now supports the privatisation of Telstra. It is a historic moment. Now you will want to clear the decks, you will want to try to ensure that there are no policy impediments around other than a GST. You think you will be able to win an election simply by being negative and getting out there and pointing a few fingers. When people say, `What are you going to do about it?', you say, `We are not going to repeal any of it. We will probably have a review, though. We will give it a big long think when we get to government.' That is the strategy. If you think that is going to work, then why don't you bite the bullet? Why don't you recognise—

talk.start.para: —Senator, you should direct your remarks through the chair, not across the chamber.

—I will indeed, Madam President. Why won't the Labor Party recognise that the privatisation of Telstra has been a very important component in the full deregulation of the market? It has led to dramatically lower prices and better quality of service. Here is your opportunity. Clearly it doesn't changes votes because no-one believes for a moment that you wouldn't go down precisely the same path if you were in government. It clearly would provide you with an opportunity to fund any promises that you might eventually come up with. It is a very good opportunity to demonstrate your policy credentials. We should all rejoice in the fact that we now have competition in every sector of the market. There is therefore no impediment to Labor coming out and supporting the full privatisation of Telstra. The only impediment is the trade union movement. There is your big chance to show a bit of independence for a change.

—My question is to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Ian Macdonald. Will the minister please inform the Senate of progress in the government's Rural Transaction Centre Program? Senator IAN MACDONALD

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to be able to tell Senator Tierney that the Rural Transaction Centre Program has been overwhelmingly endorsed by people in rural and regional Australia. In fact, I am getting a lot of letters from different communities thanking me for the work the government has done in returning to them services that left the bush during the term of the Labor government. Right across the board there has been very solid and almost unanimous support for the Rural Transaction Centre Program. I must say the only voice I have heard opposing the program and criticising it and whingeing and nitpicking is that of Senator Sue Mackay—the shadow minister for regional services, I understand. Senator Mackay apparently runs around the country—when she can get out of Tasmania; she moves occasionally into regional Australia and criticises the program. Whereas communities are supportive and very grateful that some services are being returned, Senator Mackay simply nitpicks and criticises. I appreciate the Labor Party have no policies in the regional services area; they have no policies in any area at all. All they want to do on something that is so positive is criticise and nitpick. I do not need to remind senators that Labor had 13 years to try to arrest the decline of rural and regional Australia. They did absolutely nothing.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The Senate will come to order. There is far too high a level of noise in the chamber.

—Labor did absolutely nothing. In fact, most of the services that Senator Mackay now complains are leaving the bush are services which left under the joint impact of state and federal Labor governments. Senator Tierney has asked me about the progress of the Rural Transaction Centre Program. I must say I thank Senator Tierney for his ongoing support, and all the rest of my colleagues. The Senate would know that, since we last met, the Prime Minister opened the very first rural transaction centre in Eugowra. I can do no more than quote the headline in The Land , which says `Eugowra's triumph'. That says it all. It was a great day. All the community were out there. We had the local children's marching group there. There were bands. It was a great day. It showed the support that that rural community has. A few days later I was able to open the second RTC at St Mary's in Tasmania. We issued invitations to all Tasmanian members of parliament. Regrettably, Senator Mackay, who is a Tasmanian senator, found that she was not able to come along and help the St Mary's community celebrate this great event. The last bank had left town. —I have a supplementary question. Minister, how important are these rural transaction centres in ensuring that regional and rural Australia continues to share in the benefits of economic growth that are being generated by this government?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Yesterday I answered a question from Senator Bishop and I undertook to get him some additional information on the Western Australian scene. I seek leave to incorporate this in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
On Wednesday 24 November 1999, Senator Bishop asked me, as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women:

1) Is the Minister aware of a recent study `The future is bleak: Enterprise bargaining and gender wage equity' by Associate Professor Crockett and Dr Preston? Is the Minister aware of the study's finding that, since 1991, the gender wage gap in Western Australia has increased 5.5 per cent from 17½ per cent at August 1991 to 23 per cent at August 1998? Does the Minister agree with the study's conclusion that this widening gender gap to the disadvantage of female workers in Western Australia is a direct result of the industrial relations reforms introduced by the Court government? Minister, aren't these the same type of policy measures that have already been implemented by the Howard government or are planned in Mr Reith's second wave?

2) Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The issue behind the question, Minister, was the growing wage gap on a gender basis in Western Australia deriving from the longstanding reforms introduced by the Court government early this decade. Minister, in that context could you explain why the study is wrong in starting that the experience and results of the second wave agenda in Western Australia provides `an excellent indication of what to expect in a more decentralised federal environment'?
I have provided the following answer:

1) Yes I am aware of the conference paper, which was based on the report `Pay Equity for Women in Western Australia'. I note that the conclusion that Senator Bishop refers to is not actually the conclusion of the report in ques tion. The report on gender wage gap research conducted in Western Australia (WA) did not conclude that the higher gender wage gap is the result of the Court government's industrial relations reforms.

2) The most significant decline in the gender earnings ratio that has occurred in WA since 1991 took place between August 1992 and August 1993. Over this period the gender earnings ratio (AWOTE) fell by 3.5 percentage points. However, this fall preceded the WA legislation, which did not come into effect until December 1993. The gender earnings ratio in WA is currently at the same level as it was in December 1993. This clearly undermines the assertion that widening in the gender pay gap since 1991 may be related to the WA legislation, when the Act did not even come into force until December 1993.
3) The following quote from the Executive Summary of the report, in relation to the August 1992—August 1993 period is clear:

"It is difficult to explain why female earnings have deteriorated so rapidly over this period. While female industries may have been slower than male industries to adopt enterprise bargaining (and hence fell behind in their earnings) sensitivity analysis suggests that the deterioration in female relative earning is not as a result of strong gains in male earnings over the period. Nor may we attribute the deterioration to Workplace Agreements. The Workplace Agreements Act 1993 (WA) did not come into effect until December 1993."

4) Additionally, there are significant differences between the Government's Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs Better Pay) Bill (MJBP Bill) and the Workplace Agreements Act 1993 (WA). For example, the MJBP Bill contains a range of provisions directed to promote equal remuneration that are not present under the Western Australian legislation.

talk.start.para: —Yesterday Senator Lundy asked me a question without notice regarding the relationship between Advantra and Wizard Computer Training, and I undertook to provide additional information. The role of the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts is to monitor the industry development side of the outsourcing contracts, to ensure that industry development outcomes are delivered by companies. This takes place in an environment where the contracts make provision for substitutions and variations which may arise from changed commercial arrangements. This includes situations where supplier relationships break down for one reason or another.

speech.para: My department was advised by Advantra, after the contract had been signed, that agreement could not be reached with Wizard on pricing of training services. Discussions were held with both Wizard and Advantra at that time. Advantra proposed to substitute another Australian SME to provide training. This substitution was agreed on the basis that it would deliver an equivalent industry development outcome, one SME replacing another. As it transpired, the replacement company ceased trading shortly thereafter. I understand this was not related to the Group 5 contract. Advantra has submitted a further substitution proposal more recently. Again, it involves another SME as the training provider.

Further information has been sought by my department to allow it to complete its consideration of the matter. If it is assessed as offering an equivalent outcome, agreement will be given for the substitution. I understand that Wizard enjoys a good reputation in the training field, and it is regrettable that it finds itself in this situation. However, my department is not in a position where it can insist upon Wizard being reinstated on industry development grounds. It does have the ability to guard against the diminution of industry development outcomes and it is doing that. The government's industry development policy is directed towards encouraging Australian firms and, in particular, SMEs. It is not directed towards any one particular Australian firm.

Senator MINCHIN

talk.start.para: —Yesterday Senator Faulkner asked me some questions regarding APEC Technomart III which I took on notice, and I now seek leave to incorporate those responses in Hansard

speech.para: Leave granted.

Was it the case that in the lead-up to APEC Technomart III, a number of APEC: countries suggested to the Federal Government that they would have preferred Australia to fully fund participation by them? If so, will the Minister advise the Senate which APEC countries made this suggestion?

No economy formally approached the Federal Government indicating a preference for Australia to fully fund their participation and available officers do not recall any informal approaches to this effect.

China and Chinese Taipei (Taiwan) approached officers of my Department suggesting that their delegates be given a reduced rate to participate in the event. My Department explained that it was a private sector event and suggested that these economies approach the private sector organisers regarding their request.
These very economies, together with Russia, provided the largest delegations to APEC Technomart III.

On the basis of participation by means of an exhibition stand, the following economies participated in APEC Technomart I and not in APEC Technomart III: Canada, Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, Hong Kong, and Korea.
On the same basis, the following economies participated in APEC Technomart II and not in ALEC Technomart III: Canada, Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, Hong Kong, Korea and Indonesia.

On the basis of paid exhibition stands (excluding free APEC economy booths), the following economies participated in APEC Technomart I and not in APEC Technomart III: Canada, Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, Hong Kong, Korea, the United States and Chile.

On the basis of paid exhibition stands (excluding free APEC economy booths), the following economies participated in APEC Technomart II and not in APEC Technomart III: Canada, Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, Hong Kong, Korea, Indonesia, the United States, and Chile.

talk.start.para: —Yesterday Senator Harradine asked a question about private health insurance and the waiting periods for supplementary benefits. To that question I have an answer which I undertook to find for Senator Harradine, and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
SENATOR HARRADINE—Madam President, I have a brief supplementary question. Could the minister please assess what other funds have done in this particular regard as well?

This was a supplementary question by Senator Harradine to Senator Herron on 24 November 1999. This question refers to whether health funds change their waiting and notify their members in advance of any changes which affect them.

The Government recognises the need for health fund members to be fully aware of any changes to health fund products to reassure themselves that they have the product that best suits their needs. The Government recently agreed to amend the National Health Act 1953 to ensure that health funds notify members in plain English of any change to their products including waiting periods, before the change takes effect. This legislation has now been passed. It means that members should always be aware of any changes to waiting periods that affect them.

Health fund members are able to approach the Private Health Insurance Ombudsman if they have any complaint against their health fund about waiting periods or any other matter. Data on the number and nature of complaints received is included in the Ombudsman's annual report.
Waiting periods for hospital tables have to be within the maximum limits set under the National Health Act 1953, that is:
12 months for pre-existing ailments;
12 months for obstetric conditions; and
2 months for any other condition.

Health funds are free to vary their waiting periods within these limits for different health treatments on each of their hospital products. The Act does not set maximum waiting periods on ancillary products. The waiting periods for each currently available product are shown in health funds' brochures.

subdebateinfo.title: World Trade Organisation: Biotechnology Working Party

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I have some further information in answer to a question asked of me yesterday by Senator Stott Despoja relating to the WTO, biosafety and a proposed working group on biotechnology. This information has been given to me by the Minister for Trade. I seek leave to have it incorporated. It basically supports what I said yesterday.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The information read as follows—

Australia has not been amongst the group of countries formally supporting a Canadian proposal to establish a Working Party on biotechnology in the WTO. However, if a consensus emerges that there is a need for a Working Party, we could accept its establishment provided there is a clear terms of reference.

Australia nevertheless supports discussion in the WTO of issues related to trade in agricultural biotechnology products. We do not favour the inclusion of other biotechnology products such as pharmaceuticals, for which the existing international and domestic approval processes are working well.
Other aspects of biotechnology are under consideration in other forums, with, for example,
Codex examining issues related to human health and safety, and
the negotiations in the Biosafety Protocol looking at issues related to preserving biodiversity.
Australia's view is that existing WTO Agreements cover trade in biotechnology products.
The SPS (Sanitary and Phytosanitary) Agreement allows countries to prohibit imports of any agricultural good based on a scientific assessment of risks to human, animal or plant life or health.
It also provides for provisional measures to be adopted while an assessment is carried out.
There is no obvious reason why discussion in a WTO Working Group on Biotechnology, if it were established, should have any effect on negotiations to conclude the Biosafety Protocol.
The Biosafety Protocol is aimed at establishing a regime for science based assessment of potential risks to biological diversity from transboundary movements of living modified organisms.
This is entirely consistent with WTO rules that also require science based assessment of potential risks.
Labelling of products to provide consumers with information about whether a food contains genetically modified organisms falls under the WTO Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade (TBT Agreement).
This agreement does not prevent countries from requiring labelling of foods produced using gene technology if this is to meet legitimate objectives, such as the prevention of deceptive practices.

However, the agreement requires that such labelling not be applied in a manner which would constitute a means of arbitrary or unjustified discrimination between countries or is a disguised restriction on international trade.
We would not expect the establishment of a working group on biotechnology in the WTO to constrain countries from adopting national labelling schemes for such products under the TBT Agreement.
As you will be aware, the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council has decided that all food produced using gene technology and sold in Australia and New Zealand should be labelled accordingly.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Justice and Customs (Senator Vanstone) to a question without notice asked by Senator McKiernan today, relating to funding for legal aid.

In asking this question, Senator McKiernan raised an issue which, although not of immense importance to the government it seems, is of immense importance to ordinary Australians, and that is access to their rights, access to the system of law and access to the courts of law through Australia's legal aid system. Senator McKiernan raised in his question a reference to the current Chief Justice of the High Court and his concerns on the question of this government's cutbacks to legal aid.

It has to be said that some three years ago we warned the Attorney-General that his approach to legal aid in his unresearched and unscientifically developed cuts to the legal aid system was going to cause problems that the system could not handle. Now it has to be said, three years later, that this Attorney-General will not be remembered for much, but he will be remembered for what he has done to Australia's legal aid system.

What he has done to that system has been essentially twofold: he has decreased the funding and he has crippled the national nature of it. He has essentially made a mess of it. He has made a mess of it because he cut back without consultation, without research and without any planning at all. At the time, it was not just the opposition that said the Attorney-General's policies were going to backfire on him and the system. The courts themselves—quite unprecedently in those days—from High Court judges to lower court judges all warned the government. And it was not just the courts, it was the profession, it was groups representing Australian veterans, it was groups working in the field with lower income earners in our community, and it was so many people who had access, and who needed to have access, to our family court system. They all warned the government, and the government ignored all their warnings.

We have had another warning in recent days. We have had another warning from the Chief Justice of the High Court, following on from the previous Chief Justice of the High Court and his warnings as well. Chief Justice Gleeson suggested, just a few days ago, that the costs of delays and inefficiencies caused by unrepresented litigants rivalled the costs of providing legal aid. What we said to the government was that, if you take away assistance to legal aid, then you will bog the system down because more and more people will have to appear before the courts without representation and, in doing so, would clog the system up. This is exactly what Chief Justice Gleeson said just a few days ago. He said:
Providing legal aid is costly, so is not providing legal aid.
He went on to say:
What is real and substantial is the cost of the delay, disruption and inefficiency that results in the absence or denial of legal representation.

In essence, what you have is a situation now where, more likely than not, self-represented litigants will cross-examine on irrelevant issues. They will raise matters which are not pertinent. They will ask leading questions. They will not put propositions fairly to witnesses. As a consequence, those people who are uneducated in the system of law will be basically left to pursue cases in the way that they know best and do damage to the process.

What is happening is that damage is being done, as was stated by Australian Law Re form Commission spokesman Dr Kathryn Cronin in this current debate. The Law Reform Commission's research shows that, in cases of self-litigation, there was a significant correlation between having a lawyer and getting a settlement on a case. The Law Society of NSW also said that it took up to three times longer for courts to deal with cases where there are unrepresented litigants. Such delays, said Ms Margaret Hole of the NSW Law Society, affected other parties to cases because they had to pay their legal representatives for the costs associated with the delays.

But it is not just the other legal representatives that pay; the system pays. The Chief Justice of the High Court said that, at the moment, because of this government's cuts, `28 per cent of litigants were not represented in the last financial year in appearances before single judges of the High Court'. I must say, worse still, in respect of the Family Court—a court where you do need to have a quick and efficient system—more than one-third, in fact, 41 per cent, of litigants, are unrepresented. This is the mess that this government has got the legal aid system into. Previously, we had a national system; a system which was recognised as best practice worldwide. But now, because of this Attorney-General, his lack of vision, his lack of strength and his lack of planning, we have a mess. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Of course, everything Senator Bolkus said has the air of a beat-up about it. He said Attorney-General Daryl Williams will not be remembered for very much. Daryl Williams was a very distinguished president of the Law Council of Australia and, during that time, he introduced things like video conferencing so that people from distant states, like Western Australia, did not have to expend huge amounts of money travelling to the cold capital Canberra in the east to appear before the judges of the High Court.

speech.para: To say that somebody like Daryl Williams, who also contributed very much to the reform of law in Western Australia, was somebody who would not be remembered for very much is really quite nonsensical. He contributed to the Law Reform Commission, both in West ern Australia and nationally, in a very substantial way and for those contributions was awarded an Order of Australia. To claim that somebody like that, who is perhaps one of the more distinguished people who have held the office of Attorney-General of Australia, will not be remembered for very much simply underlines the hollowness the comments that Senator Bolkus made today.

Legal aid funding was cut because the federal government believed—quite rightly—that the states should be contributing more to the cost of legal aid funding and because people were seeking legal aid for matters which really were not appropriate. As I said, it was the view of the federal government, firstly, that the states should contribute more to the costs of legal aid and that the focus of the issues which legal aid was provided for should be narrowed to matters where legal aid was genuinely appropriate.

When it came to office in 1996, the federal government was concerned that the existing legal aid agreements no longer served the needs of the funder governments. Those agreements were concluded at a time when the Commonwealth's position and responsibilities were governed by circumstances different from those which now apply. The funding provided by the Commonwealth for legal aid is based on the level of Commonwealth matters assisted by legal aid commissions in the period 1995-96. This was agreed with all states and territories prior to the implementation of the new agreements.

Funding for Commonwealth matters has been preserved. The subsidy for state and territory matters of $33.158 million per year has been removed. I think that is a very fair and proper thing for the Commonwealth to have done. The Commonwealth should only be providing legal aid for Commonwealth matters. It is not a Commonwealth responsibility to provide legal aid for matters which are essentially within state jurisdictions. I find it curious that Senator Bolkus should not recognise that point. His point of view seems to be that the Commonwealth should be providing a bottomless pit of money to anybody who wants to claim legal aid for any kind of matter whatsoever. Quite clearly, that is an absolutely unacceptable principle upon which to operate. The Commonwealth quite clearly has a responsibility to provide money for Commonwealth issues, and that is what under this government the Commonwealth is doing.

Under the current legal aid funding arrangements there is sufficient funding available for Commonwealth law matters. The focus has shifted away from funding criminal law matters, which tend to arise under state law, at the expense of family law matters, which for most of the Commonwealth, but not in Western Australia, are of course a Commonwealth matter. Consequently, the quarantining of Commonwealth legal aid dollars means that family law is no longer subsidising criminal law. I think that is a perfectly reasonable situation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In speaking to the motion moved by Senator Bolkus let me firstly commend Senator Eggleston for his defence of the indefensible. But I guess it is easier defending the indefensible if you are doing it from a position of ignorance, if you do not know what you are talking about. Clearly, those last comments by my good friend and colleague from Western Australia indicate that he is talking from a position of ignorance. Senator Eggleston either does not know or fails to recognise that now 35 per cent of the people in the Family Court are self-represented. They cannot get access to legal aid. Family law is a Commonwealth matter, as defined by the Commonwealth, yet one-third of the litigants in the Family Court do not get representation. The reason for that is your good friend and colleague, the man who will be remembered for slashing legal aid, the Hon. Daryl Williams AM. So you have learned a little bit now.

speech.para: Let me just draw Senator Eggleston's attention to the `agreements' that were negotiated. They were not agreements in the traditional sense of the word. The Commonwealth made a decision in cabinet—a budgetary decision—and said to the states, `This amount of money is going to go to legal aid, based on this formula. That is what you are going to get,' and the states had to agree to that. When some states hung out for it, the funds were just withheld. The situation went into real crisis, a greater threat of crisis than thankfully we have at the moment.

In our state of Western Australia, Senator Eggleston, let me just tell you how it worked out and how well we were done for. On a proportional basis, from the agreements the Northern Territory got 12.91c per dollar. Western Australia fared worse than any other state. The Law Council of Western Australia will not be commending the Hon. Daryl Williams for making the good citizens of Western Australia—his own state—the poor relations in the whole deal.

Let me just use this opportunity to deal with another matter—that is, the matter which the Legal and Constitutional References Committee raised in its report which was tabled in June of last year. We said, and this is a unanimous statement:
The Committee notes that it took the Government 14 months to respond to the single, unanimous, recommendation in the—
legal and constitutional—
Committee's First Report —
on legal aid—
and 11 months to respond to the recommendations in its Second Report . The Committee considers that this delay is unacceptable.

They were preliminary reports, a prelude to the third and main report of the committee. This report, together with its 22 recommendations, was presented to the parliament in June last year—some 17 months ago. In that 17 months, the Attorney-General, our good friend from Western Australia, the Hon. Daryl Williams, has either been sleeping or sitting on the report because we have not got a response.

There is an understanding in this place that the government will respond to committee reports within a period of three months. He has had six times that amount of time to respond, and there is no response to the recommendations in this report. He is treating the people and organisations who made submissions to the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee's inquiry into the legal aid system with contempt, and it just is not good enough. It particularly is not good enough now as those agreements in brackets are about to be renegotiated.

The agreements were to run for a three-year period, and that expires in June next year. Hopefully the negotiations on the agreements will start soon. They will have to start from a basis of knowledge, and they have to start from a basis of understanding, not from what Senator Vanstone, representing the Attorney-General, said here in response to my question that the government cannot talk about legal aid. The government has to talk about legal aid. The government has to recognise that there is a crisis in the delivery of justice in this nation, and the reasons for that crisis lie clearly and squarely at the doorstep of the Attorney-General, the Hon. Daryl Williams.

talk.start.para: —I too rise to speak on this particular motion moved by Senator Bolkus and acknowledge the importance of this issue. But I also want to try to correct some of the propositions that have been put before us here today. We saw Senator Bolkus consistently play the man, as he does, rather than address the issue. Senator Eggleston dealt with that, so I am not going to dwell on it other than to say that at least Senator Bolkus stayed true to form in terms of the way he deals with issues. It is probably because he does not understand or knows little about the issues.

speech.para: At least Senator McKiernan did try to address the issues that he sees with his eyes and that he thinks are the failure of the government. When we came to government, a whole range of areas in terms of legal aid was not being addressed. A number of the states failed to meet their responsibilities. There was also a failure by the previous government—and I can run through the failure list like anybody else—to deal with rural and remote areas. The previous government failed to deal with the issues concerning women in our society. It is a matter of balance between your allocation of resources and what you do.

In the time I have available, I want to deal with some of the initiatives that the Hon. Daryl Williams has brought in to the legal aid system to deal with some of the holes that existed there after the previous government. I do not think it does a lot of good in terms of debates for us to stand up here and say, `You failed on that.' It does not really achieve anything at the end of the day, and Senator McKiernan knows that well.

talk.start.para: —That's what you're doing now.

—I will start where I have a self-interest. We have allocated a further $12.4 million over the next four years in order for us to meet the increased needs for financial assistance of respondents such as farmers to native title claims. That is just one that you people could not even address.

speech.para: Let us go a little further. The coalition will provide $27.9 million over three years to establish the Federal Magistrates Service. The Federal Magistrates Service will have a less formal judicial culture than the existing courts and will reduce costs and delays for litigants. Once again, it is a very necessary reform in terms of the allocation of resources. Let us look at women in the law—another area that you people failed to address but the Hon. Daryl Williams has picked up. We have held a national domestic violence summit with the states and territories and provided $25.3 million over 3½ years to fund initiatives to assist victims of domestic violence and educate those involved in committing such crimes.

Senator Eggleston also mentioned the fact that we have dealt with the issue of new legal aid agreements to ensure there is a fair balance between the Commonwealth and the states in funding legal aid. It is rather interesting that Senator McKiernan, in his contribution, said that, in effect, we held a gun to the head of the states. The only reason firm action had to be delivered in this particular area was the previous government had failed to do so. They had let the state governments get away with not accepting their responsibilities, and they were draining the Commonwealth purse in terms of those particular issues. At least the Hon. Daryl Williams was prepared to deal with some of those issues before us at that time.

Let us look a little bit further. This year the coalition allocated an additional $3.6 million over three years to fund five additional community legal services at high need regional centres as well as to enhance the outreach services. The new services will be established in Broken Hill in regional New South Wales, in the Gippsland area in Victoria, in Kalgoorlie in our own state of Western Australia and in Mount Gambier and the riverland in South Australia—another very necessary initiative in terms of dealing with some of the particular problems.

I do not think anybody in this Senate would not like to be able to do more.
